content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												In Memory of the Dujardin Brothers.On June 13, 1999, Squaddie Henri Dujardin, age 32, and Squaddie Bernard Dujardin, age 38, were killed in action during the defense of Berlin, Germany from the Alien menace. Many civilians became chryssalids within hours, and upon the arrival of X-Squad 3 the city was overrun. The Dujardin Brothers were the first out of the Skyranger and began their mission with fervor. Captian Leonid Torban, their comanding officer, was very fond of the two, "Bernard could hit a muton from 15 tiles away and never miss! Henri, well, I guess he was good with grenades? He was the only one to not kill his own squadmates with explosives". Soon, however, the two were separated from the rest of their squad due to a cyberdisk pinning them in a small building. Nearby chryssalids soon took advantage of the situation and attempted to swarm the isolated agents. The brothers made a final, valiant stand inside the house. Henri set up multiple explosive traps at the entrances to the building and Bernard provided covering fire from the second floor. It seemed the Dujardins would make it.The cyberdisk was destroyed by fellow X-COM agents in a flurry of missiles. As it exploded, it caused a breach in the walls of the Dujardin stronghold. A lone chryssalid was able to infiltrate the building undetected, and while Henri had his back turned, the chryssalid impregnated him. The transformation was swift. He became a shambling, grotesque mockery of his former self, his mind devoured by the chyrssalid's poison. Bernard witnessed his brother's demise in pure shock. Sensing this was his final turn, chose to make the ultimate sacrifice. He placed a number of high explosives inside the room he was barricaded in, and pressed the detonator. The only thing that remainded of the building was a single ruined wall. Bernard had managed to eliminate 5 chryssalids as well as his former, turned, brother. Unfortunately, there was no body to recover. Berlin was saved, but at a high cost. Hundreds of civilians lost, 5 agents lay dead, and one turned in to an alien. The victory was sour.Bernard was promoted to the rank of captian and Henri to sergent upon their team's return to their HQ somewhere in the apparently unimportant part of Europe.With the alien threat gone, Berlin began to rebuild. Destroyed structures needed to be cleared to make room for new construction. Only one very special ruin was spared. The wall. It was made into a memorial, the Dujardin Memorial. It lists all of those who lost their lives in the battle, with Henri's and Bernard's names at the top. A new warcry has been established by the agents of X-COM: Remember Berlin!10/10 would relive again.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												When people ask me: "Mark, you like PC games, what's your favourite game?" I respond with "X-Com, with the - in it" and they often get confused with the modern XCOM, but I further clarify with "The one from 1993". Which is normally the point where they pretend to look at their watch, make an excuse and walk out of the room.So why in 2015 is my favourite game still this? Well firstly, I'm going to outline what makes this game so special. And then to wrap it up, I'll tell you how you can enjoy it in the modern world. Because for me this game is still my personal favourite.X-Com puts you firmly on the back foot from the very start. Aliens have invaded and it's your job to mount Earth's final defense against the Alien foe before we are all killed or enslaved or something happens (the intention of the invasion isn't clear to begin with). What you spend most of the game doing, is trying to shoot down enemy UFO's with your rubbish fighter jets, and then trying to fight the Alien's at the UFO crash site with your poorly equipped troops.I use terms like "rubbish" and "poorly equipped" because you are fighting Aliens here. Not Germans, not Japanese, not another nation - but mother-♥♥♥♥ing ALIENS. These guys have better weapons than you, better vision than you and more resources than you. They flew across the galaxy to fight us, and the only thing you can do at the start of the game is fight them off with humanities best and brightest, which just isn't enough.This means that your troops will die. A lot. And it's mean, and it's unfair and the game is obviously hard because of that. But at great cost of life, humanity is able to claw it's way back and slowly put up more of a fair fight. As you recover Alien technology from your encounters, and spend time researching it, the X-Com scientists are then able to reverse engineer the technology into better equipment. This can be armour that can survive a few shots, or better weapons, or ground and air vehicles. Slowly but surely, humanity is able to avoid extinction.You are fighting for the very survival of the human race, and that's not meant to be easy. Fortunately the game equips you with the systems you need to be successful but it's on YOU to work out how to do it. This is a game where you might have to watch some tutorial videos on YouTube or read the manual[cdn.akamai.steamstatic.com]. And if you do these things, you will be rewarded with one of the deepest and enjoyable single player experiences that you can have.So if you read this and you're willing to invest a bit of time to enjoy the game. After all, it is only £3! I recommend you use OpenXcom[openxcom.org] to play the game. You won't be able to launch the game through Steam, but it gives you much better performance on modern systems than playing the original game through DOSBox. The alternative is that you check out Xenonauts which is a faithful recreation of X-Com using an updated UI, better graphics and a bit more automation (such as not having to order ammunition and things). I know it sounds a bit odd, but Xenonauts is so faithful to X-Com that if you don't think you can cope with how dated this game is, I would encourage you to treat this as a review for Xenonauts. Other than very minor tweaks, and a change to air combat, they are essentially the same game.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Also known as UFO Enemy Unknown. The original (1994) was super buggy and nearly unplayable on newer systems, but thanks to these guys (the people working on the openxcom project) the game is now playable and with lots of bug fixes.The game is pretty unbalanced and exploitable, here are a few tips: -  Don't exit the craft in the first turn as the aliens, that have visual on you, will have full AP and will likely reaction fire. -  Always have the maximum number of soldiers in the landing craft (while this might be obvious, I saw people that don't do this, usually the same kind of people that spend all the APs exploring instead of having some AP for reaction fire or retreat).  - Put the most expandable soldiers closer to the exit of the landing craft because the first ones out are the likeliest to get killed.  - Don't hurry, especially getting your troops out of the landing craft.  - Advance slowly, only extend yourself when you have an alien’s location and you can kill it because you don't want it to have a full turn while you are in sight. Expanding on this, try to kill all the aliens that you see in the same turn that you see them; that's why it's usually best to advance slowly (to have lots of APs) and have lots of soldiers (and implicitly firepower).  - You should use scouts (~rookies) that at the start of the turn will try to advance but also retreat at the end. This way you'll create a buffer and decrease the chance of enemies sneaking close enough to the rest of your (more valuable) soldiers.  - Exploit: After turn 20 the aliens are generally going to come and try to find you, useful for landed/crashed UFOs.  - A very good starting location is in west Lebanon so that you will have cover over Europe and a lot of the downed UFOs could be in North Africa where the desert maps are pretty smooth.  - The beginning (or better said the first half of the game) is going to be pretty brutal, use all the force that you can and don't shy away from explosives and leveling buildings even preemptively in some cases. Pros: great feeling, nice combination of tactical game, researching stuff and base building while under pressure to survive. Cons: exploitable, unbalanced, bad spotting/FOV mechanic, you see as much as the aliens only in full light which will lead to a lot of frustration. Rating: now, we are prodding *them*! Recommendation: only if you are into this kind of games and you can tolerate/like the graphics.http://pixelloot.com

												This game is freaking awesome, after 20 years it's still amazing.There are so many good things to say that is difficult to decide where to start ...- turn based strategic combat, take your time to decide your strategy- research based on alien captured technology, this keeps me motivated to keep playing- management of resources of your bases, full control of your assets- recruit soldiers and see them evolving ... and dying :)- if you are spending too much money, you could sell things and even fire people!- air combat is simple and effective- and every element is this game has an effect on other parts: A) resources captured in the battlefield will give you new research paths and money B) research will give you new stuff to build C) stuff you build will make you more powerful in the battlefield D) more battlefield missions will give you new resources As a Sci-fi aficionado this game will give you plenty of funny hours.Absolutely recommended, if you haven't played, do it now!!This game is a masterpiece!!

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												I do own the new xcom enemy unkown and within, and i must say even though they are both really challenging and enjoyable, they don't compare to the original.X-COM: UFO Defense has an tense feeling, like everything could go wrong at any moment, something thats present in the new one but not as strong. I swear while doing missions, my hands shake, especially if i've grown attached to a character, who could die at any moment. The game gets difficult fast, any free time you have should be spent preparing for battle.Pros-tense music makes the missions scary-whenever you lose a soldier that you took the time to name, it hits you right in the feels-aliens arn't pushovers, they will mess you up-addicting, I always have to get my fix, that only the original can provideCons-I wish i could choose my starting base layout, i always have to move stuff around-black characters apear white on the battlefield, get hard to keep track of good people-can't undo actions on the battlefield, somehow this makes he game more tense-knee high walls make the worst cover, and you always have to walk around them leaving you open to alien fireObservations and tips-civilians are stupid as hell, and they always run into the aliens-alien in corn field = death-never stand next to a window, you will die -never pull the pin on a gernade unless you have enough action points to throw it -first soldier that steps off of the skyranger always dies, choose wisely-don't get rid of any weak soldiers, use them as meat sheilds for your better soldiers-DO NOT GROUP YOUR SOLDIERS TOGETHER, aliens have super gernades that will kill all of them-always have a few worthless soldier on your team to look for aliens, or take gun fireI would recommend this game to any person  who loves turn based, squad management games.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												"If aliens invaded the earth, how would we respond?"I think X-Com: UFO Defense answers that question perfectly.Launching its attack against players in 1994, X-COM: UFO Defense (UFO: Enemy Unknown to Europeans) has the player building bases across the globe, researching alien technology, and keeping the aliens from taking over/destroying the earth and making humans their slaves.Touted by many strategy fans as the best game ever, the game has a rather high difficulty, but the learning curve isn't that steep, thankfully. The aliens start sending more and more of their better troops the better you do, though.I'm not sure if they were going for a Nightmare Fuelish atmosphere or not, but they sure managed to get one, especially on the game's battlescape, with the only music being just a low, pulsing drone. It's especially creepy during the nighttime missions.If you're looking for a challenge, this game can certainly give you one, and yes, it IS fun. I feel confident you'll like the game, so I can recommend it in good conscience.

Posted: January 5
 Classic Turn-Based Strategy Game      Don't let the hours played fool you.  I bought this game back in 1995 for the Playstation 1.  It was cheap, and I didnt really know what it was.  Gave it a try, and it hooked me.  Im sure I have over 1000 hours into this game.  Several play throughs, alone, and with friends hotseat each controlling a base, and finally was able to crack the super-human difficulty setting.       Graphics are very dated, but the gameplay and challange is more than still there.  No hand holding here.  It really easy to go into a mission and have your whole crew wiped out really fast (Blaster Bomb).  Or once the aliens find your base, defend it or its gone.  Once you meet your first Chryssalid, Sectopod, or Ethereal, you will throw all your old strategies out the window and want to give up.      Buy it if turn-based strategy is your thing.  You won't regret it!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on November 11, 2010 I've been occupied by XCOM for the past two weeks straight, and it's been a blast. XCOM: UFO Defense is simply one of the best games ever made.The gameplay is deep, addictive and atmospheric, and does a surprising amount for a game from 1994. Your task as leader of the newly formed project for the defense of earth from aliens is to stop alien raids and abductions by shooting down their ships, ambushing their landing parties, and destroying their bases. Eventually you are tasked with taking the fight to the aliens and defeating them altogether. There are two modes of gameplay, the Geoscape and the Battlescape.In the Geoscape (real time, variable time speeds), you build bases around the world, dispatch interceptors and dropships to deal with UFOs, do research, manufacture and purchase weapons and vehicles, and try to please all your sponsor nations so they don't reduce their funding. However, it quickly becomes apparent that both human technology and the funding from sponsor nations are both completely inadequate for the task. In order to survive and stop the aliens, you need to capture alien technology, research it, and produce your own copies, and then sell the excess loot for mounds of money.The Battlescape on the other hand (turn based tactical, top down) allows you to control your squad of soldiers (who improve over time in surprisingly sophisticated ways) in attempts to stop the aliens. But don't think it will be easy. The Battlescape is an unforgiving world filled with aliens waiting to snipe at your men from distant cornfields and ambush you from around corners. The first several missions you play, it is likely that you will fail spectacularly. This is entirely intentional, and really contributes to the atmosphere of the game. You really feel like you are learning on the job, facing a totally unknown and technologically superior enemy who holds all the cards. A genuine feeling of satisfaction accompanies finally being able to defeat the aliens in a mission (albeit with heavy losses), or re-engineering your first bit of alien weapon tech. The lack of a tutorial actually helps the game in this way, as it is much deeper than it first appears, and it feels very authentic to learn the ropes of the game in this way.The graphics and sound are marvelously retro, and might take some getting used to for some of the less open-minded gamers out there, but I assure you the reward is worth it. Overall, this is a game that you MUST play if you call yourself a PC gamer at all. It joins a myriad of other gems from the 90's that modern gamers are continually ignorant of, though they inform modern developers every single day. There is no better indication of the current stagnation of game development than playing a game like XCOM and seeing how incredible it is. This game with an extreme facelift would be strategy GOTY.

You don't want any X-COM remake? You want good old stuff? This is what you should 	definitely do!1) Buy this on Steam2) Go to http://openxcom.org/about3) Install OpenXcom! (and maybe some community mods for fresh gameplay)4) Enjoy OLD XCOM OPTIMIZED for both new and old generation of players"The goal of the project is to bring back the tried and true feel of the original with none of the issues. All the same graphics, sound and gameplay with a brand new codebase written from scratch. This should give it:Fixability: Play the game natively without any need for emulators or fancy hacks, with none of the limitations and bugs that plagued the original. No more 80-item-limit, personnel limits, funding overflows, disconnected facilities, broken proximity grenades, floating soldiers, etc.Moddability: Tweak the game to your heart’s content. Sure the original was pretty good, but maybe you just think it could be that bit better. A nicer base layout, better laser weapons, maybe challenge yourself with a custom game mode, or just put in all the crazy stuff you’ve always wanted! None of it is hardcoded.Flexibility: Port the game to any platform you like, customize it to your liking, or use it to make your own far-fetched remakes. The code is fully documented and open-source so anyone can take a crack at it.Originally posted by your parents:It's 10/10 and you should try it!PS: Images that will make you say OMG what a good clickbait![openxcom.org]

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Full disclosure 1:  yes, I played the game back when it first came out.   So one CAN accuse me of a nostalgia bomb.    But I am  not reviewing X-com UFO defense from my memory of playing it 15 or so years ago, I am reviewing based on recent play throughs.   And it still has all the charm that it had from the start.Full Disclosure 2:  I played the Vanilla steam version for a while, then noticed comments on something calld OpenXCom.   (easily found on the net).    It's a free, extensive overhaul with many mod choices built in.   Very easy to set up; you do need to have a vaniilla version (steam version works for me...no disc required, and it is pretty cheap).    Some of the many choices are PSI on/off; improved H. Lasers,  choices for setting up your first base rather than accepting the default, and so on.   Highly recommended.Ok, the actual review.    It is one of my favorite games of all time (not judging it in its release time frame, but CURRENTLY).      The graphics are last century, iti is true.   But the gameplay is +++++.     It is tough; there is a lot to figure out, and things never seem to happen in an orderly fashion.   Sometimes you just have to give up a mission;  sometimes you just have to give up a game.    The aliens like to win, LoL.   It's a lot of fun to grind through a mission successfully, but there are no guarantees.    One of my criteria for a top notch game is whether it provides not only fun, dangerous stuff to do throughout, but once in a while something unexpected happens that blows me away.   Like  when I found out if I through a grenade on a roof, that it could bounce, and if it bounced into an alley it would fall to the ground, and if there was  a hidden alien there you would hear a muffled explosion and then....the alien death cry  you hardly expected.    First time that happened I had to save and quit for a while...I was laughing too hard.If you like challenges, tactics, and turn-based games, this is a must try out.   Good luck, andI I hope you can stop those monsters!

content:
Posted: January 25
												Ignore the low playtime, while using OpenXCom Steam doesn't log your hours. Speaking of:  GET OPENXCOM. It's a free, open source upgrade that you can use to fix a bunch of bugs and make the gameplay experience much smoother.That out of the way, X-Com has aged surprisingly well. Sure, it's a DOS game, so there's a certain degree of clunkiness to it that you can't quite shake, but the gameplay mechanics are all solid. This is a game that punishes mistakes harshly, but that also rewards a deep understanding of mechanics and effective tactics. If you've never played it before then you're going to have a rough start, but don't give up just because you get crushed a few times. Eventually you'll figure out how to keep your rookies alive long enough to deck them out with lasers and power suits. When you get that far and the alien invasion starts to pick up the pace, things get intense.And, for the time period, the art and music are decent. They're a little quaint by today's standards, but you may still find yourself humming along to the simple loops here.For $5 you can't go wrong. This is a serious gem and a permanent classic. It gets copied by other franchises all the time for good reason.

Posted: October 18, 2013
												Man, what a tough game. The main thing that makes X-COM different than Enemy Unknown is that this does its best to be a full simulation. This entails a lot of things.Room's full of smoke? Don't run around in there too long, or he'll run out of energy and go unconscious. Guy with a live grenade in his hand took a plasma bolt to the face? No problem, just run over there, scoop it up, and lob it over yonder. Want more global UFO detection and interception ability? Build more bases, and struggle to keep them funded.This game's so hard, Beginner mode is damn tough. Half the fun in this game is learning from every time you lose, unless you're a ♥♥♥♥♥ like me and savescumm constantly. I still get a kick out of it anyways, especially when the skyranger drops you directly into a house (random map generators for combat encounters).PROTIP: Get OpenXCOM after you buy this game. AFAIK the Steam version doesn't use OpenXCOM, and OpenXCOM almost completely eliminates compatibility issues with modern systems.

content:
Posted: February 3
												X-Com:UFO Defense, also known as UFO: Enemy Unknown, is one of the best games I have ever played in my life. No list of the best games of all time is complete without it. (I have put many, many hours into it, just not through Steam).The 2012 remake is a very good game, but still doesn't quite do it justice.<Public Service Announcement>: Make sure that you PLAY IT WITH OPENXCOM.http://openxcom.org/git-builds/OpenXCom is a free rebuild of the game that utilizes original game assets (so you still need to actually own this game). It fixes a bunch of bugs, and improves various interface inadequacies. It's still the same game, just polished more.It also adds easy moddability, with some mods already added to the base installation but completely optional. So you can play completely vanilla, with an experience indistinguishable from the original game except for the absence of bugs - or you can play with a number of common sense improvements - or you can download mods that change and expand the game.</Public Service Announcement>Now, why is X-Com so awesome? It's got an enjoyable X-files-like atmosphere of investigating aliens. It's got difficult but rewarding tactical combat. It's one of the few games I know where "emergent gameplay" is not a meaningless phrase  - the way you can chain your low level actions into fantastic strategies. For some very simple examples, you can have one guy carry missiles and pass them on to another who carries the missile launcher, or have have one guy set the timer on a grenade, throw it to another, who throws it to another on the front line, who then throws it at an enemy... the 2012 game doesn't let you do that.It lets you name your characters and watch them grow in abilities, which causes you to become attached to them and invested in their survival and success. And yet the game can be very unforgiving, and anyone may die with a single bad decision or some bad luck, no matter how skilled and well armored.The research, base management, etc. are fairly simple but fun. And then defending your base against alien retaliations, and seeing the same layout but on the tactical combat screen, is quite satisfying. You've built your base too open and without enough choke points around the entrances to defend against a swarm of enemies? You're going to have a hard time...One of the best things about the game is how you're essentially fighting against a "master race", the Ethereals, who dominate all the other races they send against you with sheer mentalistic power. Their psionics sow terror and confusion among your troops, and are powerful enough to augment their atrophied bodies and let them be as fast, strong, and dangerous with weapons as their client races specifically bred for muscles or whatever. And then you can build a squad of soldiers who can beat the Ethereals at their own psionic game. Humanity, ♥♥♥♥ yeah!There are many other reasons, big and small, but I'd be here all night.What's not so great about this game? Very little any more, at least if you patch it. But historically:Bugs. The most notorious was the difficulty bug, which meant no matter what difficulty you chose, you were playing on the easiest. I'm not sure if Steam uses the patched version, but play with openxcom, and it won't be a problem.Interface woes. Again, use openxcom and most of it goes away, even though the game looks almost exactly the same.Balance woes: - Psionics are overwhelmingly powerful, which means that as soon as enemies start using them against you, you're in trouble, and as soon as you develop your own psionics, the game becomes easy even on the hardest difficulty level. You can send a few psionic soldiers to the supposedly super difficult final mission, and have them beat the final level on Turn 0 by chaining a certain ability... This is satisfying, in the "nothing is allowed to be THIS AWESOME in modern games any more" way. It does lower replayability, though, and I'd say the remake does psionics better - at least if you compare both games in their vanilla state. - money can be too easy on higher difficulties, because of all the enemy equipment you'll be selling. These issues can of course be fixed by playing the game via openxcom. For example there's an in-built "line of sight psionics" mod, which makes psionics a lot less abusable. There's also an option that makes enemy weapons explode when the enemy dies, like in the 2012 remake, which cuts down on profits from selling enemy gear.Still remaining weaknesses include dated graphics (for those misguided souls who care about that), and some interface clunkiness. The gaming industry did learn a thing or two since 1994, there's no way around that. Nevertheless, we're looking at a timeless classic that I still come back to from time to time and never fail to have fun.Edited To Add - Note to Warhammer 40k fans:If you enjoy this kind of a tactical game, look up Chaos Gate. It's largely X-Com in W40k universe.

number of helpful: 20 of 20 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Back in the day, a friend of mine had a Shareware copy for X-COM.  It only had one small mission, but I was hooked the first time I played it.  This game is the reason that I worked an entire summer to buy my first computer.  I told my parents it was "for school" but I knew better.  That summer job was dirty, hot, sweaty, and tiring while loading people's junk into trucks and warehouses.  I cleaned out attics, basements, and barns that hadn't been touched in ages, stunk like rot, and had dead things that used to be furry woodland creatures.  But it was all worth it.  By the end of the summer I had two grand to plunk down on a 486 DX2 50mhz with a 350 meg hard drive.  And I made sure it had at least 4MB of RAM in it, because a game like this deserved it.    So, yeah, this game is a definite thumbs up for me.  It had so many layers - RPG, Strategy, Research, Politics, Finance.  And you were responsible for all of it. Forget to load up that special ammunition you needed from storage?  Move on bud.  If your prized soldier bought it in a fight? Then it was too bad.  Put your team too close together and they get wiped out by a grenade?  Tough luck.  Sure, you could reset/reload but that was not the way the game was designed.  You could even get nasty with your tactics - load up a soldier with as many grenades as he/she could carry and run him/her right into the alien ship.  Most gamers have a game or two that they have such great memories of.  For me this is X-COM.  It is a little rough around the edges compared to today's games.  There are portions that are not "convenient" and some missions just go sideways even though you think you did everything right.  But it is still a solid turn-based experience.

number of helpful: 14 of 14 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												There are games that are good. There are games that make you addicted. Then there is XCOM...It's the end of the 20th century. In response to growing alien threat, few governments decide to fund and XCOM organisation, solely dedicated to neutralising forementioned threat. Player becomes Commander of the force. Game consists of two levels. On the Geoscape, you manage bases, research (come on, all this sweet loot left by deceased gray cabbage. I know you want it.), manufacture and more. Starting with single base (preferably western europe, you have radar coverage over whole Europe, part of Russia and Northen Afrcia), few soldiers and fighters equipped with conventional terrestial weapons. It is sufficient for the first few weeks, but after recovering UFOs and aliens, both dead and in custody, you will get better equipment: Laser weapons with unlimited ammo, powerful plasma-based armament, durable armors, UFO-looking fighters or even possibility to make your soldiers use their Psionical abilities against aliens. But to get this, you need to get some UFOs down. Send an Interceptor, and use his persuasive rockets to make aliens crash. Then, Tactical level starts. Before engaging remaining UFO personel, you have to equip them: only equipment on the Skyranger (XCOM troop transport) will be aviable. Then you investigate crash/landing site, eliminating survivors of the crash and savaging their technology (ones that havent been destroyed during firefights, that is). Honestly, these are emotions: when panicked rookie accidently kills enemy Muton (typical tank) that was hidden in the fog of war with a rocket launcher, ready to kill my whole squad. Taking your first Etheral alive (remembering these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s can mind control♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you). The moment you have to choose wheather to lose your best soldier and have few remaining ones get back to Skyranger to escape, or risk all of them to finish the mission. Taking out your first allien base. Oh, yes, different mission types. Other than fighting with crashed/landed UFO crews there are few more battle types. In order to make XCOM look incompetent, aliens can launch a Terror mission on one of the cities. In these missions, your score is determined not only by your casualities compared to the aliens killed, but also civilians alive at the end of the mission. Not engaging in this type of mission makes it almost certain that nation will sign a secret pact with aliens and leave XCOM project. On the other hand, when you encounter 10 chyssalids on the terror mission (community hated, extremly dangerous terror unit), that country can go **** itself. Having a base close to the battlefield makes everything a bit easier. Therefore, it sould be no suprise that aliens will try to build bases on the earth. For you it's a pretty nice target: tremendous amount of artifacts can be salvaged, as long as you manage to neutralise the crew. To make it all a bit more balanced, you might find that one of your bases (you should have few of them, to have world covered by radars) will have visitors from outer space. Just saying. Last mission type is obviously visit on the Red Globe, where you put end to alien invasion. IF you won't get destroyed by the time you are ready.Research and Manufacturing are important parts of the game, though simple: Labs discover and invent things, and engineers make them. Amount of the research topics is also worth mentioning, since there are no fewer than 60 topics, most of them giving new items, few of them giving you UFOpaedia entries, and few ones required to go to Mars.Overally, i find it quite sad, that this game is much more complex than many modern games. If you manage to get through ancient graphics and interface, a bit challenging controlls and few other tiny problems, you get very good and addictive strategy.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												X-COM UFO Defense. To clear up some easy confusing this about the original X-COM, not X-COM Enemy Unknown that for some bizarre reason is marketed as UFO Defense in the USA.UFO Defense was a bona fide classic even back when it was released. You play the role as the supreme commander of earth or some such and must build bases, train troops and research technology as you try to stem the tide of invading aliens. Most of the management aspects take place in a pseudo real-time interface where you look down on the Earth and pick where to build what, which soldiers to send where and so forth. Once you've shot down a UFO or simple found one that's already landed however the game switches down to a Turn-Based tactical map where you must find and eliminate every alien you see. Different elevations, as well as the ability to remove cover and peak into buildings by using explosives keep the game challenging.As you progress through the game a bit of storyline unfolds as the aliens ramp up their invasion of earth and you are through a series of events lead towards the opportunity to stop it once and for all.UFO Defense is a classic game that should be played by any fans of strategic/tactical games. It might not have held very well with age but it's still one of the best games in it's genre.

content:
Posted: January 8
												You don't need that month of your life.  Or sleep.  Or food.  You need XCOM, and the deep satisfaction of creating a chain reaction of Cyberdisk detonations.This game has earned its legendary status.  It's not the graphics or the research or even the plasma weaponry.  It's the gameplay mechanics, which seem to me to likely have their roots in strategy games one might play with dice and miniatures.  You have to choose what kind of attack you make, what direction, and when.  You have to choose which item to research, what to build, and most importantly, try to predict your enemy's actions before there's a grenade in the middle of your squad.  I love this game, even if a single combat can keep you invested from dusk till dawn.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												For me, it's the game of games, the best one among those 500+ in my library and 1000+ I've ever experienced on any platform, not to mention thousands and thousands of hours in my life I've spent on gaming.My reasons for this choice are, in order of importance:1) it's a turn-based strategy, so I can think or drink as much tea as I wish between turns,2) it's very role-play friendly, since invasion is happening in our times, on real planet Earth, within lots of real countries, you can place your bases anywhere, and you can name every soldier as you want,3) it has an enormous amount of various quality content — graphics (art for technologies and interface, the interface itself, gameplay graphics), texts (the whole story and technologies' descriptions), gameplay items (loads of light, automatic, heavy weapons, clips, explosives, equipment), sounds (both interface and gameplay), music (simple but atmospheric),4) it's incredibly simple to play even if you have no user manual or have little to no knowledge of English (the only issue would be to progress with the story, but even then you may play tactical battles infinitely and enjoy them),5) it's random enough to have high replay value, but rather consistent to be played with many different tactics,6) it's sci-fi (and I'm tired as hell of elves, orcs, zombies, World War II, and alternative history),7) thanks to OpenXcom project, in our days the game is fully cleared of all bugs, and the interface has all necessary enhancements since the latest patch from the long-gone MicroProse,8) again owing to OpenXcom project, the game is fully moddable and has outstanding total conversions like XPiratez — you should eventually check it out if you have another spare lifetime.This is my favorite for almost 20 years, and will remain the same till the very end, whether good or bad it is for the industry.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I've spent enormous amount of time playing that game.It has only one minus, the game is old and so is the picture. It takes time to get used to it.Other than that - it is the best must-play turn-based strategy, in my opinion.Like in new XCOM, there are two parts - turn-based combat and economical simulator on global map. In the global part you set up the base (up to 6), build all kind of facilities, in order to research, copy, manufacter and then sell alien technology-based staff, thus making yourself financially self-sufficient. Build lots of storage rooms and collect prescious ellerium. Lots of ellerium. Also, there you hire soldiers, screen off weak, and manualy customize the strong ones. Make up capable squad.You have a lot of freedom in the global part to make a separate game from it , however the real kicker of the game is the squad combat part. If you are new to a game aliens will often beat you up on easy difficulty. And it hurts. After 100 h X-COM becomes something like chess. You start using exploits like it was designed to do so. There you can master superhuman difficulty. After 200h of playing and reading a lot of material from X-COM wiki you can easily kick chrissalid terror mission's butt during the night on superhuman using only conventional weapons. And even then, when you feel super confident, sometimes, soldiers, you became so attached to, you trained so well, all die, due to grenade relay malfunctioning. In one big kaboom. Well... when humankind is on stake, no person is irreplaceable and the fight continues.

content:
Posted: January 31
Product received for free
												My Score for this GEM is 11/10.ATM, it's free @ HumbleBundle. Grab it!If you are a strategy games fan but are too young to have seen this game, please get it and play it on DOS box (to make scrolling slower). Resist your urge to quit when you see the pixelated DOS graphics.One of the best strategy games ever, with many sequels and successors and hardly any of them reaching the greatness of the original. Of the modern offerings, maybe X-Com Enemy Unknown and Xenonauts come somewhat close. Still, the complexity and "realism" of the original is amazing. Fire rockets which put grass and trees on fire, which then spreads, creates smoke and illuminates environment at night. And smoke blocks vision and can gradually make soldiers unconscious. Complex line of sight calculations in 3D when a soldier uses a flying suit in a partially destroyed multi-stock UFO. Fully destructible terrain and loot. Motion sensor grenades and guided rockets. Hardly any of these things where decently implemented anywhere else.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2013
												Okay, my original version of this review was terribad so I've decided to redo it to do this game justice. First and foremost, this is one of the best games ever made. It has been over 20 years since this game was originally released and it is still every bit as good now as it was back then. Not even Enemy Unknown (Expect a lot of comparisons by the way) can quite match up to how enthralling this game is.   So let's get some problems out of the way first; As much as I wish XCOM: Enemy Unknown would let you have more than a maximum of 6 soldiers in a mission at once, this game goes completely ♥♥♥♥ing overboard with it. At first it's not too bad, letting you initially field 14 soldiers a mission at once. It gives you a generous amount of troops without it being too unwieldy. However late game once you get the final transport you can field 26 soldiers a mission. This not only makes soldiers feel a little too expendable (Which can lead to some pretty hilarious things to happen when your higher ranking officers are in trouble) it also makes some battles incredibly laborious especially when you're unloading your troops from the transport. Then there is the user interface which will be completely baffling for new players. Seriously, it can take a while to actually get used to it. If you can get past it, though, then I guarantee you will fall in love with this game.   Okay now that that is out of the way; The actual strategic battles that take place are perfect. Fully destructable environments combined with every weapon being able to freely target any tile adds countless strategic value and can make or break any situation. Then there is the time units system. As great as the two move system in Enemy Unknown is, it doesn't exactly work as well as the time unit system in UFO Defense. Let me explain: Time units act as a kind of currency given to each unit on the field in order to perform any action be it moving, crouching, shooting, or looting. Oh yeah, that's another thing that's better about this game, you can loot dead enemies as well as fallen XCOM soldiers. This is a really good feature that allows you to have tiny victories by letting you take some alien artifacts or carcasses even when the aliens have almost completely annihilated your forces. Then there is also the game's night missions. Unlike in Enemy Unknown, depending on where the battlefield is taking place, night missions can be legitimately creepy and frustratingly difficult early game. It helps to build this really tense atmosphere that even in late game still retains a little bit of its magic, and it's only amplified if there's a chryssalid lurking around.   Okay now let's move on to the Geoscape... well there is a lot more micro management in this part than both the Battlescape and Enemy Uknown combined. I personally like it; it makes me feel more like I'm running a military base with all the little things that ultimately don't add much value to the overall game, but are pretty nice to have anyway. However I will always always ALWAYS prefer this Geoscape over Enemy Unknown's Geoscape. Why? Because this Geoscape actually let's you be proactive by letting you patrol your interceptors over areas that seem to have a lot of UFO activity instead of that god awful satelite mechanic in Enemy Unkown (which I will explain in more detail why it is bad in my review of Enemy Unknown once I finish the game.) The interceptor battles themselves don't have much more depth in this game, but they go by so fast it's not a glaring issue. Also, deploying your troops to deal with aliens doesn't run as much of a risk of losing a country's support as it does in Enemy Unknown, and as a result makes the aftermath of the council report much less annoying.   There are some things that I haven't addressed about this game in this review, but it's already long enough and I feel I've covered all the important stuff... Even if this turned into an old XCOM vs new XCOM, but after playing both games a lot it's really hard for me not to compare them. It's still amazing how well this game has aged over a couple decades as opposed to others, and I still stand by what I said in the first paragraph that XCOM: UFO Defense is one of the greatest games of all time.10/10 (Because I can't refrain myself from giving games I review a score)

Posted: April 1
												Super game! One of the true classics, and - according to me - one of the best games still in modern times!Note: A patch openxcom.org fixes pretty much all of the bad usability issues in the original game. This is probably a must-have if you are going to enjoy the game today.This game is super for people who likes strategy and management. Unlike the later series of X-Com (partly but mainly after Apocalypse (game #3)), the features of the game has been overly simplified to make the game suit a much wider audience. This game, however, is the real deal... superb for those who like a good challenge and the management involved.Pros:- Best inventory management ever, including later X-Com, and possibly most/all other games as well. - Excellent base management, economy management etc.- Quite realistic; maybe apart from that aliens are attacking the earth.- Decently good turn based fights.- Each soldier has unique stats- Units are ranked in far more stats than the later games (again, this game is a bit hard core, and may not fit everyone).- "Missed shots" may actually hit someone/something else! Just because you don't hit your main target does not mean that the shot is harmless; which the two latest x-com games need to learn from! Standing 5 units in a line is a really bad idea.Cons: - Psionics is far too powerful. I would prefer having line of sight to the enemy in order to use it. Once you've got a few good soldiers with psionics, the rest of the game is pretty much over - and with a little bad luck only, you can lose pretty much an entire squad if you lose a soldier in the ship on the first few turns.- No heavy armor option available from start - requires research.- Blaster launcher is perhaps a bit too imba as well.For example: If you need object X from a mission, if you've picked it up and successfully evaced the soldier, you've got the item later in the game as well; unlike many later games where you can't pick up stuff from the ground.If the mission is going south, you can load your soldiers with as much valuable items as possible prior to evac... in many other games, you cannot pick up bodies of enemies, carry extra weapons (carry 3-4 main-hand weapons, just for transportation) etc.Note: A patch openxcom.org fixes a lot of the bad usability issues, like that it was impossible to save equipment layout, set an order in which units start the missions etc. For all players (new and old), I highly recommend downloading this!

												Kiss your life goodbye. You're with X-COM now.X-COM UFO Defense is one of those few classic games that truly changed gaming forever. content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												This is the game that XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Xenonauts was/are trying to remake. That right off the bat should tell you that there's something special about this game if people are trying to recreate it ~20 years after it came out. That there's something here that people just can't let go of.Turns out it's the truth. The UI is extremely archaic, the graphics speak for themselves, and the game lacks many of those "modern improvements" like autosave and such. With that said, this game was vastly ahead of its time. And its still good despite its age. It's very similar to Enemy Unknown in many respects (aliens invade, shoot their UFO's down, stop terror attacks, eventually eliminate the alien leader, etc), but there's alot that didn't get to that game as well. Multiple bases, no class system, larger battles in general (the top level air transport allows you to bring something in the order of ~26 troops into a fight), assaults on your bases if you don't chase aliens away from them, and more. It's harder than EU, longer than EU (took me close to 50 hours to beat this opposed to 20-30 for EU), and in some ways is a larger game as well.It's still a great game, though some might be turned off by how it looks. But if you can give it a shot, you can very well find a game that, even if it is one of the oldest games on Steam, is still an excellent mix of fun, challenge, and replayability. Just watch out for the Chryssalids. They are much scarier in this game. o_o

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
-Quick Review-X-COM: UFO Defense is a strategy game developed by MicroProse Software Inc. in 1993, at the time the game was revolutionary, and is commonly cited as one of the first strategy games many people played, the game is extremely difficult, especially if you've never played it before or any other X-COM games. -Detailed breakdown review- Story:  I would love to give more details about the story... but, I haven't progressed very far into the game, so all that I can say regarding the story, is probably what you already know; "X-COM is a project that is supported by various nations to defend the Earth from Alien Invasion".You will have a great degree of control over the location your base will be constructed, buildings inside your base, troops, scientists, engineers, aircraft, and weapons for your troops or aircraft. Being a strategy game lover, the only way I can describe the detail put into this game from the 90's is "beautiful". ...I just wish I was better at playing it. Game Play: As I eluded too earlier in my review, there's a lot of customization available in the game, generally starting out most people have the same strategy, and if you intend to pick up this game, I highly recommend checking out guides online, or steam guides. You will most likely need them.It should be noted that the fan base for X-COM have put out updates for the game, I never took the time to look into any of them, but they supposedly make the game much easier to play. I just decided I will work with what steam game me. (something with the DOS Box, updating DOS box, or downloading a whole new client, etc. If you want to know more, Google or go to X-COM: UFO Defense forums)For people in the unique situation where they HAVE played X-COM: Enemy Unknown, there are a remarkable similarities in game functions, and strategies. I was able to figure out most of the beginning Base, overview, scientists, and engineering controls and tasks, without needing to look up anything online......It was the battle phases that lost me, I spent 2+ hours of my time learning how much fun it was to get murdered by aliens, (mind you: I'm playing on easy difficulty, I thought I could take a few shots to the face... nope, just nope. Just one *zap* and you're toasted-carbon-molecules.) Achievements: Beating this game, or getting far into the game is an achievement. It's called "being good at old/classic video games" and I wish I was, I really do. But these games help remind me that even though I succeed in most video games and get achievements for jumping off cliffs and dying, that I really have achieved nothing. Regarding steam achievement... Nope,  nada, and that's just fine with me! Price:  X-COM: UFO Defense is $4.99, a package deal getting you five classic X-COM games goes for $14.99 (best deal, if you know you like these games). I personally bought this game from a Humblebundle. Conclusion: Here's the real question: "Will you enjoy this game?" and the answer is... probably not.But this is someone's childhood, just like Commander Keen is mine, therefore I cannot cast my vote to "not recommended", this game is really amazing that it was from 1993, and it started the ball rolling for an outstanding strategy game series that helped shape strategy games today.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												X-COM: UFO Defense is a fantastic game if you are the sort of person who likes turn-based combat mixed with basebuilding and management.The gameplay consists of managing your base on a world map, where UFOs show up at regular intervals. After you've scrambled some jets and nailed those suckers, a "mission" becomes available. The mission consists simply of sending out your forces to the crashsite where you have to eliminate survivors in turn-based combat.During the game your forces will become stronger and with the help of research, new and better equipment will be available for production. This will come in handy, seeing as the aliens also become stronger and more resillient as the game progress. I find that the difficulty curve is quite nice, up to a point when the most powerfull weapons become available, after that the game becomes a little trivial. Still, this does not happen untill late in the game, and that's more than a couple of hours of gameplay.The turnbased combat I find very entertaining. There is a load of different aliens with different abilities, all of whom are dedicated to kill your elite soldier squad. Some will make you moan in annoyance, as they take control of your soldiers, and others scream in terror as they charge forward and impregnate your soldiers turning them into "zombies". Atleast that's what I did when I first played this game as a very young little boy.The graphics and sound in the game is well, old, but many a great game survives purely on gameplay, and this is one of those games. The graphics are probably the games biggest weakness, but also one of it's charms I think. This is an old school game, for old school gamers, specificly for the type that likes turnbased combat with a mix of basebuilding. So take a trip down memory lane and give this little gem a chance - also make sure to get help on the boards on setting up the game...

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
 Warning this game is Hard. This game is infuriating. This game can be rage-inducing  But man if this game isn't fun... This game is just another one of those games that comes right out of my childhood. I remember when the first laptops where open to sell to the public and the military had given a free laptop with training on their use (wow right?). My dad got a Compaq Presario, which I still have, This game was on there along with Colonization, Civilization 1-3, and Warcraft. However this game holds a special place in my heart, I was terrified of this game as a child and would  have thought of it as a horror game. But I digress, this game is what the latest game XCOM: Enemy Unknown is based on. This game is insanely hard even though the difficulty setting is a myth. Now mind you this game is old so graphics are not 2016 quality but, that being said this game still charming in a soul crushing way. You can set up every mission with 14 soldiers and you should expect a 50% mortality rate being a good mission resolution. Now on the plus side you can have multiple bases all over the world and set them up how you want. Research is slow and the aliens have a clear and painfuly humbling advantage to you even when you develop laser weapons which are one of the first research option. Which is a testament to its difficulty. Terror mission are the last thing you want to see on your map, and the best solution for the alien menace is to chase them down over the ocean and then shoot them down so as to hopefuly delay the inevitable beating you will recieve by the aliens long enough to get tech that it won't be a massacare. The only forgiving feature is that you don't loose council members and just a small portion of funding which can be suplimented by selling things you make.Inspite of its age with clunky controls and sometimes absurd difficulty I recomment this game. It is affordable and its sequal, X-COM: Terror From the Deep is even crazier than this game. If you are a glutton for punishment and want a challenge and enjoyed the updated version. I would highly recommend that you get this game

You will also build a base and add hangers barracks etc to it (You can select where the base is located in the world). You must know that x-com is very old and very hard, aswell as beeing hard the game never explains what any buttons do to find that out you can either google it or find it out yourself. This game is a true gem and should definiatly be experienced and keep with it because it will take some time to get used to it.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												After playing the new XCOM, I couldn't get enough so I ended up purchasing this game. One of the best decisions I've ever made. While the graphics are incredibly dated, but for being 20 years old (and counting) aren't bad at all. I highly recommend finding the Open Xcom mod after downloading, it updates the UI and makes the game playable by modern standards and fixes many, many bugs (and is the only way I play the game). The formula made familiar by the new game is if anything stronger and more sandbox-y as you get complete control over your base layout, your teams are 14 instead of 7 and there are a lot more events and pressures than the new one. It is also much harder, but as a result more rewarding when you beat it.The only real negative is the lack of a strong cover system (it's fine, but not the awesome system from Enemy Unknown).Score: 9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												X-Com is a game I have become very fond of long after it's time has passed.As a squad tactics turn-based strategy game, it's by no means for the faint-hearted, as overly-aggressive tactics are almost always promptly punished with the loss of one (or more) of your own units.  This is a game where being OCD can usually pay off.Featuring a massive tech tree for both the aircraft to shoot down UFOs, and for your ground forces to have better weapons and armor to defeat whatever aliens may actually make it to the ground, not to mention the amount of detail put into the game's research entries, the game has a sound amount of content.The actual combat is solid, featuring mostly destructable terrain, and a lot of gratification for successful operations, and plenty of chaos for a turn-based game.  It's detailed enough for a strategy-game fan to get immersed in, if he/she so wished.All in all, it's an often-overlooked gem that I believe everyone should play at least once.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												I gotta say, I have XCOM enemy unknown, with all of its DLC, and I bought XCOM 2 with all of its DLC, the same day that I bought this in the complete pack. This is the one that I'm addicted to. I've never played it growing up, so I'm not nostalgic over it or anything, but I'm honestly more addicted to this game, than the new XCOM 2. That says a lot. I feel like it's almost infinitely more in depth, but in a somewhat simplistic way, compared to the new two XCOM games, and that's why these older ones will always stand the test of time. They're just great. The new ones are great too, so don't hesitate to check them out either. The only problem with these older games is that they run off of DOS BOX, which means that they save to your computer, rather than the steam cloud. I have a desktop, and a laptop, and I play games on both, and I have to play two seperate campaigns, because the saves don't carry over. It's totally ok though, I'm more than happy, and can't complain. Check this game out, it's a classic!!!

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												[Edit] - OpenXcom is not a game, it's only a mod. Keep in mind, that I am wrong in the review below!6.8 megabytes of fun.It's pretty ruthless for beginners of the series, since you don't have a clue what to do, how to do anything (all the buttons in the fighting mode for example, no descritpion at all) and when to do something. When to buy another base, hangar and so on. This is my first X-COM game I have played in my whole life and it is a lot of fun. But to be honest? I would rather play the new XCOM game called "Enemy Unknown" if you are new to the series, since it features more modern visuals (duh) and is far easier to get into. X-COM: UFO DEFENSE though is not a watered down version is definetly more complex. You get to make more choices, but the downside of all that is its clunkyness. Those game mechanics are more than 20 years old, keep that in mind. I had no problems playing this game on Windows 10, so this is definetly not a worry you should have. My advice anyway: get OpenXcom. You get to play at higher resolutions and you are able to zoom out, which is pretty neat. The game was not meant to be played in 1080p on 27", so OpenXcom is a neat "alternative"...which is free of charge. So, before you buy - try OpenXcom first. It's more or less the same game, so you get to know if it's worth the 5 bucks for the original.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2012
												Said to be the best strategy game of all time. Not an understatement exactly. It's not as needlessly complex as most turn based strategy games. It's not as hectic as realtime strategy and it's not as shallow as most indie strategy out today. This is a really well balanced strategy game with destructable environments, funding, research, base maintenence and manufacturing. Very entertaining game and well worth the price.Story - What's it all about?X-COM starts on January, 1999. You are in charge of X-COM, an extraterrestrial defense force, funded by almost all of the major countries from back in the 90ies. Russia, Brazil, China, USA, India, South Africa, Libya, Egypt and all of the major european countries like France, Germany, UK and not some others like any Nordic ones or Netherlands, Austria. Probably because these countries wouldn't or couldn't fund a project such as an extraterrestrial defense force. Regardless, you are now supposed to cover the 'entire globe'. Well not entire, you will only have to cover the ones that do fund you and since many countries actually doesn't fund you, you can safely let aliens land in their areas. But if you're like me, you will probably want to go ahead and cover as much territory as possible anyway.Gameplay - How does it play?You are in charge of everything. You put up your base, you intercept and shoot down all of the UFOs, you lead your tactical squads on mission, conduct research and manufacture weapons. This game is amazing in all you can do and research is vitally important to you as it leads your progress throughout the game (like research bloody should!). At the start of the game you know nothing about these aliens and even as a player that kinda frightens you because these aliens, already from the absolute start of the game, they utilize far more superior weapons than your own. As the game progresses, the aliens don't really, but if you're able to stay in the game for long enough and have spent some fair amount of money in scientists you will realize that you can reverse engineer the alien technology and even construct even more superior weapons than them: GENIUS!Criticism - But what isn't that great?Well for instance, the aliens start out vastly superior to your people in every respect. This is not bad in of itself but it makes some of the future things you can construct somewhat redundant. For instance; you can construct armor for your soldiers eventually, but it doesn't protect well as the aliens fire incredibly damaging salvos of plasma matter at them which basically melts the armor instantly. Without the armor your soldiers only have 1 hit point as far as you're concerned but even with the armor they barely raise that to 2 hit points. Also, when one of your people dies; you cannot recover their armor. Which means that you must make a 20000 dollar armor for every individual you want to protect.     My other criticism with the game is that many of the expenses doesn't make much sense. For instance; you never buy interception planes. No you RENT them! What the earth? And when they get shot down (not if), you don't even have to pay anything. I think they could just as well have sold the interceptors instead, but seeing as it is the very first plane for a very long time I can see why they decides to make the planes that way. The funny thing is that the rent of bloody 600'000 dollars and you have to pay every month! I know it's state of the art but holy cow man. USA's funding is barely 700'000 - 800'000 and they expect you to have a base there plus at least one interceptor to keep all of the aliens at bay!?     Of course I am nitpicking a little but that's what great with the game: It doesn't really have any flaws other than that. Sure the aliens are hard as balls to fight but that's the point of the game!Conclusion - So what rating do you propose?I propose a rating of 6 out of 6. This game is bloody amazing strategy game. It's almost as if it was made for me. The amount of content in it is huge for a DOS game of barely 6 MB and even by today's standards it's incredibly fun to play.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Nothing holds a candle to the original XCOM.  Even if you have already played the original and have fond memories, do yourself a favor and get it again and check out the amazing OpenXcom community.  There are some amazing mods that improve AI, Movement, add weapons, add enemies, technology, maps, factions, alter difficulty, and improve balance.   There is even one mod (Piratez) that completely overhauls the original game and changes it into you leading a band of mutant space-babe Pirates on a mission to loot and pillage across the globe 600 years on an earth subjegated by aliens.  If you want the challenge of taking a crew of mutant-babes armed with flintlocks, cutlass, and chainsaws and pillaging spaceships with them.... then it is worth it.  There are even one or two Let's Plays on youtube that are worth checking out if you are hesitant.  I've been playing it for hours and I've only hit the tip of the iceburg on all the new content added into this mod.  Check this or other packs out if you feel like you've already mastered the amazing original!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2013
												Remember that show you watched as a kid about that super secret elite fighting force that protected the earth against an evil menace that wanted to destroy/take over the Earth? This is about those guys.You play as a paramilitary organization tasked with defending the Earth from an alien invasion. Of course, the bad news is that the aliens equipment is extreamly more advanced than what you can field in the beginning so its up to you to even the odds. Gameplay takes place in two screens, the Geocape which is where you manage your bases, conduct research, launch missions, and monitor alien activity across the globe.The second screen is the Battlescape. This is where you take the fight to the aliens.Gameplay here is turn based as you move your troops around the battlefield trying to kill aliens before they shoot your troops in the face with a plasma bolt.You will shake your fists in anger as your rookie trooper fails to shoot a sectoid that is right in front of him. You will morn the death of your favorite veteran soldier when they die heroically in the line of duty, you will smile with glee when you finish building a shiney new weapon that you reverse engineered from alien tech and prepare to use it against the alien menace, and you will shreik in terror when you experiance a snakeman terror mission for the first time.This game maybe old, but it is a must play for any fan of strategy games out there.(Recently, OpenXcom was released which adds a whole bunch of features (including mod support) and bug fixes that is a must have if you play this game. OpenXcom is a free download so feel free to get it after you buy this game.)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A classic game. If you are like me and enjoy classic and challenging games this game is for you.Difficult and overwhelming at first it rewards you for spending time to learn not just the aliens but also yourself and the gameplay mechanics. It is a masterpiece in suspense, gameplay control and exploration. Otherwise the aliens might decide to raid you for once.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I have completed the game at super human difficulty short after initial release.X-COM is the father of all turn based, tactical squad combat games and still today far deeper than modern games of the kind, although few.Compared to the new release of X-COM which is the closest modern game available, UFO Defence is back on graphics, modern interface, tutorial and simplicity, but if you do not mind graphics and tutorial and like to venture deep into finding a complex game secrets in tactical squad combat and out of combat strategic decisions, UFO Defence is not a choice, it is your only choice.X-COM in terms if time and what you see is the exact opposite of total war games, the 'map' which is the entire planet runs in real time or faster if you choose, and when you take any action like bases management or entering combat time pauses. In combat you play in turns, all other actions out of combat like base management are simply interface choices at paused global time.Starting up, you have an underground base with some basic few equipment and personell. You job is to deal with alien threat on earth. To do that you need to intercept UFOs with you planes when you detect them so you crash them and then land and explore with your squad. Also you need to react to other alien activities already on ground like city attacks. At the end, you squad lands near the incident, kills alien opposition and accomplishes the goals. But kill the alien opposition is not exactly easy. The second part is about three main activities. Research on alien equipment, dead and alive aliens and theories will give you knowledge for better combat effectiveness, stronger bases and progress your investigation on aliens and to understand your enemy plan - the initial title was UFO Enemy uknown. The second is manufacturing, usually based on alien findings after researching. You can manufacture weapons, armor and gadgets for your combat squad, plane fighters and their weapons for stronger interceptions, better squad carrier crafts, base facilities and defences and other. The third thing is about your bases. You start with one but you can build 8 total.The magic about X-COM is that you can do anything that later X-COM or X-COM like games restrict and present them as new revolutionary gameplay elements. But for X-COM veterans those were just restrictions. You can have a fully custom squad, from 1 man show to 32 total soldiers, replacing 4 with a mechanical small tank if you like, or two or as many tanks as you like, soldiers equipped with whatever gear from a large variaty of existing and later researched and manufactured options. You can complete a mission with dozens of real different tactics. You can expand your bases any way you like. You can build a 'research' base, or a 'factory' base or an 'interception' base or a 'military' base as i call them. Or just all your bases can be all-around.As a matter of fact, any style you want to play is doable. And every choice has effect. A tank unit for example is definatetly stronger than a soldier at start but it does not gain any experience. Soldiers improve mostly after they kill aliens. On the other hand, if you have the transportation space you may get a tank with you to salvage the situation if all goes ill. Or just do not use tanks - i do not for example. They are not overpowered or anything, but i do not like them, i prefer soldiers.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2010
												Let me start off by saying:This was one of the greatest games of all time.Pretty hefty statement is it not?  Unfortunately, if you didn't grow up in the DOS era or played the game, you would find what I say difficult to believe.  However, believe when I tell you that if you can get past the dated graphics, turn based gameplay, and some minor compatibility issues.X-COM is one of the most rewarding and fun games to play and is an absolute MUST PLAY.Shoot down UFO's, capture alien technology, then research the technology so you can use it yourself and equip your squaddies with it.  The fun part is in turning your squad of rookies into elite Captain's and Commanders equipped with the latest and greatest weapons.  This is definitely one of those games you have to play with for a bit in order to really appreciate it's excellence.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												I had never played this game before, I hadn't even heard of it.  The fact that this game is from 1993 is immediately apparent from the outdated graphics and UI. With no instructions, I failed my first mission. I promptly learned from my mistakes. The game is difficult, but fair, and even the glitches affect your enemies as well as you. The first levels are difficult if you have not read instructions, and it is only marginally easier after you know what to do. After a certain point, you feel like you aren't losing, but you never feel like you're winning. Not until the credits roll.The difficulty of the game makes it more rewarding than any recent games, despite what was expected from The lack of plot and the (really outdated) graphics. If you want to fix those problems, you can play X-COM: Enemy Unknown. It is an extremely simplified version that lacks most of the depth, but is still good when taken on its own.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												UFO - Enemy Unkown, the seminal classic turn based strategy game of the early 90's. If I had to sum up the game in 3 words I'd have to say brutal, rewarding and erm...old which brings me to my first point. Due to its age it definitely may not be everyones cup of tea. If you can see past the age related interface niggles there is a truly deep strategic experience to be had here.Truth be told I've had issues running this game for years and years but with a little reading I was always able to get it playable. There was absolutely zero tinkering needed with the Steam release, it runs in a completely acceptable state on my Win7 64 machine :)This game stole a year of my life and a year of my friends. While everybody was out enjoying the sun during the school holidays my friend and I were working on our vitamin D deficiency, huddled round a pc waging war on the Sectoid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and their slithering minions.This is not an easy game. It can be absolutely rage inducing when the RNG gods mock you from above while your crack squad get minced during a terror attack. On the flip side, the feeling you get when you beat some of the things the game throws at you later in the game is intense. The suspense of what this brutal game will throw at you next is just perfect. I loved it 23 years ago and I still love it now, while some things have not aged well the basic mechanics of the game remain as beautiful today as they were back then.A true classic in every sense of the word

Posted: December 10, 2015
Old Timer, bringing back some MemoriesIt's a long time ago, when those games were programmed and sadly, some of the games didn't get the setting as well as the original back then.Even in modern times this game still has a lot to offer, it's a hard squad style round based strategy game, oh and don't worry, you will start to hate the game as much as any new games.The squadmembers are mostly nothing more than cannonfodder, and you have to keep in mind that there are several things that you have to keep in control.Pros:Not all DOS based games run perfectly even in DOS-Box with contemporary machines. This one offered during play not one crash.A classic game, which gives a lot about the old lore of the series. Of the old series, this is the best.Cons:If you are a player that wants to have every game in your library on par to the capabilities of your PC this game might not be for you, it's old and it shows.I actually had forgotten how anoying it was to see your squad decimated one by one... oh, and check your squad members... they might choke in weaponry and amunition.Recommended just for purpose of NostalgiaThe game is good, as always, and it will always be good - if you look at the remakes made recently, you see that the story still holds a lot of live juice inside. It still fascinates players today.This given, the game actually is a game people might not used to nowadays, it's hard even on easiest mode. The Aliens often have a lot of advantage against the player (comes as no surprise though). And yeah, the endscreen can be very bitter... especially when you lose.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a really addicting and fun stragety game. if you have played the more recent xcom games this is what that is except about 5 times more complicated and hard. the premise of this game is that it is 1999 and UFOs have been spotted all around the world and it is up to you as the commander of X-COM to stop the aliens from killing all of humanity but it won't be easy.The things i like about the game is the two different types of gameplay, there is the geoscape which is basiclly base-management in which you can tell your engineers what to build and where to build it and to tell your scientists what to rescearch. Then there is the battlescape (the main part of the game) in which there are a few different types of missions: UFO landings, UFO crash sites, and then the dreaded terror missions (terror missions are when aliens invade a city and will kill any civilians they can see). Another thing i like about this game is the graphics because for its time this was a good looking game. Now it's time to talk about the negatives and one of the negatives is the aliens themselves. The aliens are a bad thing because for starters they can MOST of the time they can kill your soldiers in one shot and during night missions it seems like they can see you from half-way cross the map (there is one alien you will hate no matter what the case is) ! Another thing I don't like about this is that it becomes way to complicated later in the game. Also you will lose almost somewhere around a possible 25-50 soliders and whay is that? Well thats because this game is BRUTAL even on the easiest difficulty i still struggle to beat a mission without losing one soldier (you will need a metric ton of patience to play this game). The hud it's self if very impossible to understand unless you have watched someone play this or played it before. Also there are a few bugs here and thereOverall this is a great game dispite the few issues it has it's a awesome start to a equally awesome franchise and with it's price tag of about $5 it's worth it. (If you do get this i HIGHLY reccomend you download OPENXCOM. It fixes the games bugs and improves preformance on newer computers and it also improves the gameplay with certain options. Also my overall my playtime is about 10+ hours. Ignore my playtime it shows.) Score:8.7/10

Posted: December 19, 2010
												Depending on your initial entrance to the PC gaming genre, you may not know about X-COM. Turn-based, squad-based and definitely a game that grips your by the seat of your pants. A game that, 17 years after release, continues to scare the crap out of me while giving me a deep and fulfilling strategy experience. They don't make games like this anymore - and for that reason you owe it to yourself to play X-COM. Especially if you missed it the first time around. X-COM promises to give you a couple dozen hours of alien killing, research trees, base building and soldier naming. You will, after all, be losing lots of noobs those first few missions...
