Posted: February 1
Product received for free
												I know what the hours say, but they can't count all the years I used to play this game back in my shortly after high-school days (both PC and Sega CD).  I'll be honest, I hadn't even thought about this game since roughly those days.  Thanks to HB for this blast from the past.I see that a lot of folks picking this one up right now are mostly younger than this game is, and that's great.  The only sad part I see are all these people who try to detract from this masterpiece of 90's PC genius.  "It's too hard."  "It looks dated."  Those are the two biggest complaints I'm seeing from them...Is the game hard?  Damned straight it is, but not too much so.  It's got a huge learning curve, but it's nothing that a litle practice can't overcome.  Not to troll, but "get gud".  Seriously, though, it just takes some geting used to is all.  But, that's because it's not generally like other strategy games out there. As for whether or not it looks dated...  Well, that's a matter of opinion.  But even if it does, that's a good thing, because it still looks really awesome for the level of graphics tech at the time this game was produced.  Yes, some of the characters look cheesy with their huge Guile-esque flat tops, but at least the devs were forward thinking enough to include female soldiers as equals to the males.  So, hey all you SJW's, this game is PC friendly.All in all, if you can get it for free, definitely give it a try.  What have you got to lose, but some time?  If you can't get it for free, what's $5?  The game is well worth that and more.  Would recommend 100 times over.

												Poor? Cheap? Can't buy Enemy Unknown? Get this. Do it. It's like crack. It's only £2.99. Just a warning, this game will hand you your♥♥♥♥♥ Go watch NecroScope86's LP on this. He will teach you the ways and your game plan. You will rage while playing this. You can name your troops and it is strange how naming your soldiers to people you know makes you grow more attached to them. When they die you will probably cry like a man or shout "NO! YOU ♥♥♥♥ING ALIEN ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!♥♥♥♥♥♥" Then you buy more soldiers and name them something like "Niall Reborn" or "Jesus Christ". This game may be old as ♥♥♥♥ but it is still very playable and addictive. Like that feeling you get when you make a new base on Ireland...then the ♥♥♥♥ing aliens destroy it while it's still under construction...♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. When you actually get in to the gameplay, it is Intense and very Tactical. 1 simple ♥♥♥♥ up and mean the loss of one of you fellow soldiers. When you start you probably will be confused at first but trust me, you’ll pick it up very quick.Another thing, I recommend the UFO Extender or the OpenXCOM Mod.The steam version of this game is slow as ♥♥♥♥ and buggy. 												Poor? Cheap? Can't buy Enemy Unknown? Get this. Do it. It's like crack. It's only £2.99. Just a warning, this game will hand you your♥♥♥♥♥ Go watch NecroScope86's LP on this. He will teach you the ways and your game plan. You will rage while playing this. You can name your troops and it is strange how naming your soldiers to people you know makes you grow more attached to them. When they die you will probably cry like a man or shout "NO! YOU ♥♥♥♥ING ALIEN ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!♥♥♥♥♥♥" Then you buy more soldiers and name them something like "Niall Reborn" or "Jesus Christ". This game may be old as ♥♥♥♥ but it is still very playable and addictive. Like that feeling you get when you make a new base on Ireland...then the ♥♥♥♥ing aliens destroy it while it's still under construction...♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. When you actually get in to the gameplay, it is Intense and very Tactical. 1 simple ♥♥♥♥ up and mean the loss of one of you fellow soldiers. When you start you probably will be confused at first but trust me, you’ll pick it up very quick.Another thing, I recommend the UFO Extender or the OpenXCOM Mod.The steam version of this game is slow as ♥♥♥♥ and buggy. Any of these Mods speeds the game up and patches near enough everything.X-COM UFO Defense is a type of game I don't normally play but holy ♥♥♥♥ is it fun when you get in to it. It is extremely rewarding when you win your first encounter or research new weapons and tech. and it's all topped with a beautiful hard as ♥♥♥♥ difficulty. I highly recommend this masterpiece of a game. Get it if you can't afford the new one...like me. And even then, you should probably still get this. 10/10

Posted: February 1
Product received for free
												I know what the hours say, but they can't count all the years I used to play this game back in my shortly after high-school days (both PC and Sega CD).  I'll be honest, I hadn't even thought about this game since roughly those days.  Thanks to HB for this blast from the past.I see that a lot of folks picking this one up right now are mostly younger than this game is, and that's great.  The only sad part I see are all these people who try to detract from this masterpiece of 90's PC genius.  "It's too hard."  "It looks dated."  Those are the two biggest complaints I'm seeing from them...Is the game hard?  Damned straight it is, but not too much so.  It's got a huge learning curve, but it's nothing that a litle practice can't overcome.  Not to troll, but "get gud".  Seriously, though, it just takes some geting used to is all.  But, that's because it's not generally like other strategy games out there. As for whether or not it looks dated...  Well, that's a matter of opinion.  But even if it does, that's a good thing, because it still looks really awesome for the level of graphics tech at the time this game was produced.  Yes, some of the characters look cheesy with their huge Guile-esque flat tops, but at least the devs were forward thinking enough to include female soldiers as equals to the males.  So, hey all you SJW's, this game is PC friendly.All in all, if you can get it for free, definitely give it a try.  What have you got to lose, but some time?  If you can't get it for free, what's $5?  The game is well worth that and more.  Would recommend 100 times over.

Posted: September 15, 2013
												X-COM: UFO Defense is an often revered classic in strategy cirlces, more so now than ever before following Firaxis' re-interpretation of the series in their Enemy Unknown 2012 release. Despite being nearly twenty years old, the 4X strategy aspects are as strong as ever. I appreciate how the interface and geoscape are presented to you with next to no hand-holding. The lack of any sort of tutorial or battle advice works effectively in immersing you in a reality where your enemy threats are truly alien and in every sense of the word too. Experimentation is key, with base building allowing for different types of manufacture and research that have plentiful bounties to offer. The X-COM unit itself can be treated as if a business of it's own which naturally has numerous benefits throughout the course of the game.Yet the actual combat itself is where UFO Defence shows it's true colours, irrespective of how prepared you really are. It doesn't matter what armour you have, what guns you carry or even how experienced your soldiers are: the struggle always remains the same. Your units will miss painfully obvious shots, be felled by a single stray bullet or, most embarassingly of all, panic at the mere sight of a lone alien mook. It is because of the haphazard nature of X-Com's combat that it can feel slow and monotnous, especially as level structures repeat themselves and saves are reloaded numerous times in order to better chances against otherwise unbeatable enemies. Some people love X-COM's combat but I'm most certainly not one of themEven so, UFO Defense was a major sign-post for the strategy genre because it took these crucial features in the combat and global contest and extended them into a larger experience. Not many games to this day match X-COM for it's scale and even fewer for it's initially brutal learning curve either. Most of you reading this have probably already made up your mind about the series and it's legacy either way, to those who haven't I would only recommend you try them simply to say you've done so. If nothing else, X-COM is capable of eating up weeks of spare-time when it engrosses the best of us and that genuinely is a good thing.

												This game isn't too bad - I was expecting a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game, coz you know it's from 1993 and I've been spoiled by these modem good looking ones; but nooooooo! What I got was a true surprise! This[www.gamespot.com] actually sums up what I had in mind when I played it.....heh..but if you wanna read my review of it, then continue....Ok,so the story goes like this: Sometime in 1999, aliens have come and visit Earth and cause havoc on said planet. With all countries now putting aside their differences (or at least I think has happened because otherwise there should some sort of conflit in the middle east....with the taliban or some♥♥♥♥♥♥...hahah) have come totogether to help by funding you, the XCOM to deal with this alien threat. You, with said funds, will in return, help those countries defeat the aliens, less they sign a pact with them in which case they're doomed and you will get less(or no actually) funds from them....Gameplay-wise, it's a turned base which I like because that means I can *think* critically and not ♥♥♥♥ up a move.......but if you do ♥♥♥♥ up, there's no going back because there's no take back move button! Hahahaha YOu use your mouse cursor to point and click where you want your guys to move and or attack. You get limited amount of time units which if used up, you cannot make him move, attack or do any other action that uses up time units... There are other attributes, but I won't be getting into them - I'm trying to keep this review short... :P Graphics, ehh.....might look ugly, but once you get pass that, the gameplay is pretty fun; game uses DosBox to run of course as you can't run a DOS game on newer winows operating systems! Of course...I uuueeerrrrrhhhhh............mmmm......used a mod to make the game *less* difficult(coz I ain't no masochist as apparently this game's a true masochists' game!)......it's called OpenXcom and you can find more info here[openxcom.org] or even here[ufopaedia.org] - that place has quite a bit of USEFUL information you want to know before tackling the game..........oh and while we're on the subject, check this FAQ/strategy guide out from gamefaq[www.gamefaqs.com] by KChang - very informative if you have the time to read all of it.... And here are some more tips for beginners: 1....you can also look through the discussion board.........Sound - well doesn't sound too bad, even the music fits well! Nothing much else to be said here...Yeah, in conclusion, for me at least - running the game through the Open Xcom mod(you can install over the steam installation if you want and just rename openxcom.exe to dosbox.exe and tada, you can now have steam track your hours played and or steam overlay enabled whilst playing the modded version! I didn't do this so my 0.5hr playtime is actually false should be at least a few hrs or even several by now had I done this...oh well...) , made the game playable and I was able to enjoy it.....though there were times I had to cheat because I just couldn't be♥♥♥♥♥d waiting and wanted to power through the missions.....hahahahaaha :P That and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥are my rookies so♥♥♥♥♥♥ *Gets out the ship* instant death on first two, and rest of the crew I send out to kill that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ alien that shot down two of my men, completely missed! All and every single shot! One guy was like right up to the alien, like a square next to him and still missed his shots!!!! What the ♥♥♥♥ is this♥♥♥♥♥♥! Who the hell trained these rookies before being put forward to work for me...?! And don't get me started on those terrorists.........oh god...........yeah nah this is definitely a rage worthy game, along with SuperMeatBoy I've played and that Absconding game....But that's like for the first few or so missions....once your rookies gain a rank, or and level up attributes, they get better.......but still not as good as I want them to be though...................... I made a guy with all attributes set to 9999 and he's basically invincible - can take on a single mission by himself! hahahahahahahahahaaha.....that was fun for a good while.....Ahhh.......still need to get to the ending though....lol.....So yes anyways, I recommend because I found it fun after a while and no I wasn't feeling any pain whatsoever whilst having fun! :P====================================Played on Raikou (Gigabyte P35x V3): Intel Core i7-4710HQ, 16GB RAM (1866MHz), Intel HD 4600(driver version 10.18.14.4294) Nvidia Geforce GTX 980M(driver version 378.78), LiteOn 128GB and Samsung 1TB SSD mSATA, 2TB HDD, Win 7 Pro x64, BD-R ODD, FHD display

												Let me preface this review by noting that I did not play this game properly until 2016.  I bought the game last year, played it for 2 minutes, was overwhelmed by the UI and lack of guidance, and so gave up. It's worth it, trust me.  This is a game from 1993/4 which easilly holds up today; I'm only 7-8 hours in to playing the game and I feel a lot more coming.The music and sound effects give an eerie feel, which I'm unsure is a deliberate choice or a side-effect of the limitation of old DOS games in general.  It definitely feels like you're playing on a piece of history.Give it a real chance, modern video game player, and you will reap the rewards.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												A classic!I first played this game in 1995. It´s as fun today as it was then. The strategic chess game of the battles is always enough to keep my mind busy. Simple rpg rules, turn based. Every soldier has time units, which deplete when they take actions. And stamina units. Leaving unused time units allows your soldiers to react in enemy turn. Then just kill all the aliens.Setting up my team every single time before battle can get tiresome though. And the soundtrack is bad, though at low volume it´s not a bother.But after that. Any game that can survive in my collection for allmost 20years and played on a regular base. I must give a 100% entertainment value. And the graphics are just about as good as many indie games today.

Posted: May 31, 2014
												This is a game before tutorials, before tooltips, and before the developers cared about what percentage of players could beat any given scenario. When it lists difficultly not by degrees of easy or hard, but by levels of experience, it means it. Beginners should start on beginner and graduate to experienced when the title fits. The game start doesn't have any sort of introduction, you're just thrown into the action without an explanation or briefing. You're not well supplied or well funded at the beginning either and you'll need to justify your budget each month, just like a real government agency. I started my first game, lost, and I started over during the first in game month. To help the next person in those shoes, here's a few bits of advice I picked up while learning to play: Rookies are cheap, buy more rookies before you worry about things like tanks; aliens can see in the dark while your soldiers cannot and the entire storyline including the game endpoint (as well as a few very useful research projects) come about after capturing an alien or two alive, so electro-flares and stun rods are not useless; and finally, if you ever see a hunched-over, black, bipedal crab-like alien, get the hell out of there.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												This is an awesome game from yester-year. You may want to go look at some tutorials first, as the game doesn't actually explain what you're supposed to do at the start (this was back in the day, where you were supposed to read the manual before starting play). In short, build up humanity's defense against aliens and take them out in turn based, squad focused tactical combat. The graphics are of course dated now, but the game is still really fun AND HARD. You'll be killed a lot looking for the winning strategy.I'd also highly recommend the reboot, XCOM, Enemey Unknown. Avoid the old-school sequels like Terror from the Deep, they're just another skin on top of this game with a lot of bugs.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I'm one of those old farts who rave about this game. As far as I'm concerned , it is the best strategy game every made. The AI isn't perfect. Aliens will do dumb things and get killed but they will also outflank and ambush you too. The graphics are pure 1980's. Nothing to write home about. The movement of your troops and the aliens is clunky.  The aliens don't look very scary on screen. But this is one of those games where you'll go "Oh, *&^% are you kidding me? How did that happen?" as an alien floater you can't even see sends a rocket into your Skyranger wiping out half your squad before you even move one of them out.  Or you've moved your favorite squaddie around a corner in a terror mission, only to see a Chrissalid about 10 feet away. You try to run, but a Chrissalid has 120 TU's to your measly 40 or so. You know you're toast when the aliens get their turn, even if you do a reaction shot, cause it takes more than one hit to usually kill a Chrissalid. But the Chrissalid doesn't kill you. He turns you in an alien zombie. Your own troops have to kill you. Isnt' that fun? Playing Ironman in this game is masochistic.  This game isn't for the click-happy, over-adrenalined (is that even a word?) 21st century gamer. It's slow and methodical and takes  a while to learn to play properly. If you are willing to do some reading, there is a lot of information online for this game,  Strategy guides, tips and tricks and many other documents.  But if you're looking for a game that will challenge those little grey cells, this is it. Not only do you control the tactical combat part ot the game, but you have ot determine what to research, when to do it, what kind of weapons your squad should use, which of your team you want to keep and nurture, and which you want to use as cannon fodder, as well as many other decisions.  The main game is all about micromanagement. And one wrong move. Waiting too long to research a tech or failing to shoot down a UFO coming to attack your base can mean the difference between winning and losing the Earth to the alien invasion. It's an awesome game and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes to use their head, wants a good challenge and likes strategy and micromanagement. I highly advise playing this game a while before trying to tackle the sequel, Terror from the Deep. It's even harder than Xcom. Oh, and try to refrain from throwing your PC out the window after you lose a whole squad on a terror misison.

												This game delivers a wide variety of depth from technology research, base-building, squad customization, and tense, turn-based tactical combat! It always feels like a personal loss when you create a veteran soldier, use him or her to fight battle after battle, and grow attached to that soldier as your hero, only for the game to suddenly annialate that soldier whether it is a cyberdisk explosion, being turned into a zombie by a Chryssalid, or simply a lucky shot from a basic Sectoid. This game also does not forgive you if you leave a soldier out in the open or in another vulnerable position. For anyone who likes a strategy challenge, I highly recommend this game as a classic to add to anyone's collection.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												A classic!I first played this game in 1995. It´s as fun today as it was then. The strategic chess game of the battles is always enough to keep my mind busy. Simple rpg rules, turn based. Every soldier has time units, which deplete when they take actions. And stamina units. Leaving unused time units allows your soldiers to react in enemy turn. Then just kill all the aliens.Setting up my team every single time before battle can get tiresome though. And the soundtrack is bad, though at low volume it´s not a bother.But after that. Any game that can survive in my collection for allmost 20years and played on a regular base. I must give a 100% entertainment value. And the graphics are just about as good as many indie games today.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												This is an awesome game from yester-year. You may want to go look at some tutorials first, as the game doesn't actually explain what you're supposed to do at the start (this was back in the day, where you were supposed to read the manual before starting play). In short, build up humanity's defense against aliens and take them out in turn based, squad focused tactical combat. The graphics are of course dated now, but the game is still really fun AND HARD. You'll be killed a lot looking for the winning strategy.I'd also highly recommend the reboot, XCOM, Enemey Unknown. Avoid the old-school sequels like Terror from the Deep, they're just another skin on top of this game with a lot of bugs.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I'm one of those old farts who rave about this game. As far as I'm concerned , it is the best strategy game every made. The AI isn't perfect. Aliens will do dumb things and get killed but they will also outflank and ambush you too. The graphics are pure 1980's. Nothing to write home about. The movement of your troops and the aliens is clunky.  The aliens don't look very scary on screen. But this is one of those games where you'll go "Oh, *&^% are you kidding me? How did that happen?" as an alien floater you can't even see sends a rocket into your Skyranger wiping out half your squad before you even move one of them out.  Or you've moved your favorite squaddie around a corner in a terror mission, only to see a Chrissalid about 10 feet away. You try to run, but a Chrissalid has 120 TU's to your measly 40 or so. You know you're toast when the aliens get their turn, even if you do a reaction shot, cause it takes more than one hit to usually kill a Chrissalid. But the Chrissalid doesn't kill you. He turns you in an alien zombie. Your own troops have to kill you. Isnt' that fun? Playing Ironman in this game is masochistic.  This game isn't for the click-happy, over-adrenalined (is that even a word?) 21st century gamer. It's slow and methodical and takes  a while to learn to play properly. If you are willing to do some reading, there is a lot of information online for this game,  Strategy guides, tips and tricks and many other documents.  But if you're looking for a game that will challenge those little grey cells, this is it. Not only do you control the tactical combat part ot the game, but you have ot determine what to research, when to do it, what kind of weapons your squad should use, which of your team you want to keep and nurture, and which you want to use as cannon fodder, as well as many other decisions.  The main game is all about micromanagement. And one wrong move. Waiting too long to research a tech or failing to shoot down a UFO coming to attack your base can mean the difference between winning and losing the Earth to the alien invasion. It's an awesome game and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes to use their head, wants a good challenge and likes strategy and micromanagement. I highly advise playing this game a while before trying to tackle the sequel, Terror from the Deep. It's even harder than Xcom. Oh, and try to refrain from throwing your PC out the window after you lose a whole squad on a terror misison.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												The original X-COM! There is a lot of great things to say about this game.  Love the research & development of alien technology,  that is very natural as they are derived from items you capture from the aliens.  The mood is right, very eerie music and settings. Awesome soundtrack and sound effects. (for the time, but they are still great) They tie a lot of UFO legends into the game which helps make it more believable.  The difficulty is insane!  At the lower difficulties it is beatable, but very tough on the harder difficulties.  You have to be careful as death can lurk around any corner, you don't know where the aliens are hiding, and one wrong move is usually death. One of the best games of all time!

Posted: May 23, 2011
												If you can look past the horribad 1994 graphic resolutions, there is a surprisingly deep sandbox strategy game here, with a level of detail that competes with modern strategy titles. You possess full control over your resources, finances, bases, soldiers, fighter jets, research projects, tatics, and strategies. You can rename your soldiers to your favorite hollywood marine squad, and give them any weapon, kit, and combat role you desire; but, don't get too attached: the firefights are gritty and deadly, and soldier turnover is quite high... Place bases anywhere on the world map, shoot down UFOs in real-time, and deploy a dropship full of marines to crashsites and alien sightings and command them in turn-based isometric 3D destructible enviornments. Capture aliens (dead or alive) and their technology, then use your scientists to coax their secrets so your engineers can duplicate their tech. Take the fight to the aliens' doorstep in a climatic final battle on Mars!

Posted: May 1, 2011
												They really don't make games like they used to. X-Com UFO Defense is one of the most brilliant ideas for a game anyone has ever come up with: a combination of realistic squad tactics and a deep civ-like base management system. I've never experienced a tactical game quite as tense and scary as this one, even today. You never quite know just what will be down there when you search a UFO crash site or an Alien terror site. The way the game merges the research/development into the Alien battles is pure genius, you are never more than a couple minutes away from the next big thing you want to get. In the early 90s the PC thrived on games like X-Com in their startingly realistic and in depth simulations you couldn't get anywhere else. No PC fan could go wrong with this game.

Posted: September 24, 2015
												This is X-com.  The grandaddy of tactical turn based strategy games, and still an amazing experience to play.  If you're like me and you grew up playing, you know what X-Com is.  You'll be incredibly disappointed to note that the steam version is the European version and has differences from the NA version, most notably in the sound department.  I downloaded this, fired it up, and was immediately disappointed.  Killing sectoids especially feels much less satisfying with the euro sounds.It's still an incredible game and if you've never played it, you should.  It's a hardcore game, even in an era where most games were hardcore.   It's grueling, atmospheric, and intense, and quite a bit dated, but it's still a great game.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2011
												X-COM: UFO Defense is a hybrid of turn-based tactics and real-time management that is frankly astounding. This is easily one of the best strategy games of all time, and I'm not alone when I say that. Many recognize it as such. There's a slight wit to the game that makes it never too grim nor too silly. In addition, it's got downright brutal difficulty (leading to some of the best challenge around), a surprising amount of strategic depth, and it's immensely satisfying to win. Any strategy game fan *needs* to play this game. Period.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2011
												This is probably the worst tower defense game ever made. The idea is apaprently that it is THE FUTURE (aka 5 years ago because this game was made in the Bronze Age) and aliens have started crashing to Earth in their UFOs. You're part of X-COM, the UFO Defense team, which has to protect them. Unfortunately there are two massive flaws. One, the enemies never show up, which is a bunch of crap but it doesn't even matter because the second massive flaw is that THE ALIENS THAT YOU ARE TRYING TO PROTECT ATTACK YOU. Yeah, they basically broke the AI really badly. Your own soldiers barely even react without you telling them what to do which is pretty dumb. The game's grid-based like most tower defense games, but I never even got to set up any towers because my men were cut down by the stupid aliens. What a joke. You'd think a game made by the Ancient Romans would be patched by now.

Posted: October 25, 2012
												The original, and the best. The recently released abomination from 2k (XCOM in name only) drove me to go back and revisit this series and it has never been more enjoyable Grab UFO Extender and the patches (google "enemy unknown extended" for instructions) and marvel at this incredible classic in full pixellated HD widescreen glory, with many improvements such as base construction queueing, range based distance, automated manufacturing (so you don't have to make/sell micro to make money), and dozens if not hundreds of other major improvements. The best part is that the innovations are totally customizable... edit UFOExtender.ini to your heart's content and give yourself the perfect muton slaughtering experience. If the rubbish cashgrab they released this year was half the game this is it would be 2012's Game of the Year.

												For $5 you can own this legendary classic. Tense on all levels, this game has you sending men into field after field hunting for aliens noone has ever seen. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												The original, and the best. The recently released abomination from 2k (XCOM in name only) drove me to go back and revisit this series and it has never been more enjoyable. Grab UFO Extender and the patches (google "enemy unknown extended" for instructions) and marvel at this incredible classic in full pixellated HD widescreen glory, with many improvements such as base construction queueing, range based distance, automated manufacturing (so you don't have to make/sell micro to make money), and dozens if not hundreds of other major improvements. The best part is that the innovations are totally customizable... edit UFOExtender.ini to your heart's content and give yourself the perfect muton slaughtering experience. If the rubbish cashgrab they released this year was half the game this is it would be 2012's Game of the Year.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												After Minecraft, X-COM UFOD is my favorite game of all time. In fact it may be no coincidence that both games share common traits: they both have stellar gameplay and horrible graphics. Most game developers today seem to have forgotten a simple truth- Gameplay > Graphics. XCOM gives you command of an army of super-soldiers to fight off an alien invasion. Micro-managing is the key to victory and boy....there is plenty of that. You decide everything from where your bases will be / how large or small to how many bullets each soldier carries. The combat is turn-based and the enemy AI , while not as good as later games , can still be very sneaky.What I enjoyed most is how your soldiers *slowly* ramp up in strength via reverse engineering of captured alien tech. There are times when ( if you havent been researching fast enough) you may encounter stronger aliens and still be useing simple guns! Defeating these stonger aliens with current weapons are the great story-making events of the XCOM game.Oh did I mention the RPG elements too? Each soldier in your army has his/ her own stats. These stats can determine things like what weapon they would be best at, if they would make a great scout, a good medic, or if they should be sent packing.Any fan of RPG + Turn-base + Sci Fi games simply cannot go wrong with this title. Rivscore- 99 / 100 ++NOTE++ Yes. That's right...99 out of 100. This game is almost perfect. If the Devs would pay for Scarlett Johanson to come to my next birthday party and blow...out my candles it would be 100 / 100.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												First played it with my brother a long time ago. A very long time ago. So long we had it on one floppy disc. For a game that small, it delivered an agony of considering every move, horrifying experience of meeting the first cyberdick and then cryssa*#&^$(#ers. Back then (and i think it is still now) there was a bug that all difficulty levels played as the highest. And we thought the game was difficult on easy...The game starts with a handful of soldiers with pitiful guns, a meatshield against alien menace. Literally meat sometimes, where you step one tile too far in the night and get poked by a plasma pistol from the feckin Sectoid hiding in the wheat and you can't even see the basturd until you walk right next to him.Once you get laser weaponry the game becomes much easier. I never used plasma. Didn't see the reason to. Overwhelming laser firepower was my answer to all alien questions.I found the psionic aspect of the game to be least enjoyable of all:1. Aliens have an upper hand because they can cheat the fog of war and see you all the time so they can find the weakest link and mind-control him all the time. And, as it usually turns out, he's your commander top-level elite soldier you've been grooming for the last 50 hrs. 2. Once you get the magic powers, the game becomes trivial. Find an alien, mind-control him to reveal more aliens and snipe them from afar (accuracy is not affected by distance). Throw their own grenades at their feet. If they have a blaster launcher... well they will be scraping themselves off the geography soon.IMPORTANT: Get the openXcom mod for this game. It adds loads of features, and mods as well. My favourite is the one where your soldiers get combat ribbons and medals for their achievements on the battlefield.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												The original. Some of the mechanics are a bit obtuse and it's definitely hard-mode, but the gameplay and mechanics still hold up to this day.That being said, there are certainly better versions out there now. XCOM is a lot more streamlined and beginner-friendly, so I would honestly recommend starting there if you're not a veteran of turn-based strategy games. This game will not hold your hand. If you've played XCOM but looking for more in-depth or deeper gameplay, then Xenonauts might be worth looking into. At this point, this game is only worth playing if you have nostalgia or want to see where it all started. If you're willing to put up with the dated graphics then there's still an amazing game here.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Every once in mankind's history, new technological advances in society boosts living conditions. Although, as life is more enjoyable, the better the entertainment is desired of the human race. One video game came along in history called "X-COM:UFO(Enemy Unknown) that changed the percepetive of how turn-based tatics and the requirement of the human mind was needed to combat a very secretive but deadly extraterrestrial life that decided to visit planet Earth. You are responsible to combat these new enemies of the human race using a small tactical force of suicidal footsoldiers and badass Spartans. No matter which direction you choose to defend our "finders keepers" home planet, you will experience an intense, nerve racking experience that will be with you for the rest of your gaming career. Enjoy!ALSO! I highly recommend the "OpenXcom" mod to improve the UI and fix the bugs. Good Luck!

content:
Posted: February 19
												I'll give credit where credit is due. The game has a lot of complexity and I have a lot of respect for it and its successors (go look at my hours in EU and XCOM 2).Having said that, this is a game back from the days where you got control manuals. The Steam version does not. It's like trying to learn how to pilot a goddam submarine that's about to explode.All my troops get about four steps off the unloading ramp before a Cyberdisk gibs them, leaving the derpy laderhosen clad civilians to their doom.  You can probably figure out with some crash courses on the internet, but frankly I just can't put that much effort into a game I spent 1.50$ on. If you grew up with this and know it, go back to it and love it the way it deserves. Otherwise, if you're like me, just stick to EU/XCOM2.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												First off, I loved this game back when it came out, and still love it. Many have tried to clone this game and "improve" upon it, but there is just no beating the classic.So why am I not recommending it?If, like me, you played it and loved it, you have no need for my review, get it and have fun.If however you never played this game, it is hard getting into and the graphics may put you off. I am fully aware that part of me still loving the game is nostalgia, something you will not have as a new player. There are still things that annoy me in this game, like hunting for the final alien in a map, when they are off hiding somewhere. It can get so frustrating that I would send soldiers everywhere, hoping they get shot at just to reveal the enemy. The new XCOM reboot solved this by adding noises that your soldiers can hear to direct you to the enemy.Also, once you have the game figured out, you can get overpowering very easily, with endless amounts of money from producing and selling weapons, to supereasy levels where you can just mind control all the aliens and have them kill each other.

												X-COM is remembered by many old-school gamers as the uber-difficult, tactic-heavy, turn-based strategy game of earth's defense against aliens.While it is still all of these things, it is very difficult to play this game today when there exists the new X-COM games with modern day conveniences. If you've played this game before, it may still get a playthrough thanks to nostalgia. However, if you have never played this game before, it is doubtful that you will both understand how to play this game, nor find it worthwhile to actually play through it.While it may not really have stood the test of time to be playable to the masses, it is a title that will always be remembered by those who enjoyed it many years ago.4/10 "Not worth playing today"

number of helpful: 8 of 33 people (24%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 30
												With nostalgia this game is probably great. I played it back then and even hex-edited it heavily to create modified game logic (upgraded ship weapons, single-supersoldier game mode etc.). The way it's designed is very motivating, and the fact that you start very weak is something you don't find in many games these days where it's all easing-in. It is so much more rewarding if you built everything on a difficult start.If you've not lived in that era of gaming though, you might want to skip this (and get the new game which was modeled after this original and thus understandably is massively popular), because the technical implementation seems crude. The DOSBox mode likes to resize program windows you might have open, and during my brief tests it rarely ever accepted mouse clicks on the globe nav buttons, and some menu sound effects were delayed.So I ran the windows version and it asks me for the executable every time and then automatically also launches some kind of fix-EXE. Whether I do this or run the EXE manually, the game only gives me a black screen. I hear intro music in the background, but no keys are accepted. I have to terminate the process.Too bad. I wanted to at least check whether the Windows version has better usability.Reviews say to install OpenXCOM, but I'm not motivated enough to do all that modding stuff these days.After all, I've played this game to death many years ago, hah.

number of helpful: 15 of 52 people (29%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												This game is a gem for its time, maybe even one of the best - yet most complex and demanding - pieces ever created on personal computer. Hopefully the presented claim is only little exaggeration. *UFO Defense* gameplay includes multiple aspects such as financial and supply management, base construction planning, research and manufacture organisation, big view world-defense with hypersonic jet planes and later innovative solutions; soldier recruitment and training, as well as turn-based tactical ground combat that the reviewed product pioneered in great extent. Recovery of alien artifacts and technology with their adaptation to Earth-based equipment is crucial to ones development in pursuit of defeating an enemy, whose abilities and ravagery increase with time.Memories of fine hours dedicated to exploring the world endangered by alien invasion - and its only shield, the international X-COM force - brought me back to this product. I am still under impression of its uniqueness. Nevertheless, for present day, this DosBox version - that STEAM claims to be Windows-compatible - is far from working acceptably. Five euro/dollars for a program older than twenty years is robbery considering the current standards. If you are going to buy *UFO Defense*, do it only for the sake of *OpenXcom* - a fan-made and well done upgrade that greatly enchances the playability of the game, next to optimizing it for modern systems. *OpenXcom* requires the original *UFO Defense* data. Know, yet, that this data are remote files that ought to be available for free already.Is this game difficult? Whether it is difficult or easy for someone who already knows how to play it, is one thing - but to learn how to play it on minimum required level, is other thing - and that may be tough; be warned. It is a nostalgia purchase nowadays. User-friendliness is hardly a feature here.I truly admire *UFO Defense*, as well as impressive input that the fandom had into making it so much better experience, therefore I need to be fair with what we get on STEAM at the moment [2016] for the price of five euro/dollars: thumbs down. DosBox version is out of play.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
 Certainly a classic, but a product of its own time I can see why this game and its sequels are so revered: the sheer scope of your options is so vast and varied, you really get the feeling that you're a part of a much larger world, and it's not simply a game script feeding you pre-determined scenarios.However, this is one of those very old games that have "unwritten rules" that you only come by after repeated attempts at trial and error (e.g. always use "Auto Shot" instead of "Aimed Shot," dedicate your resarch to such-and-such immediately, don't use tanks because they're useless, etc.). Given the complexity of this game, you can expect to lose many, many times before making the tiniest smidge of progress. Even the many FAQs and walkthroughs that exist give contradictory information (not to mention that one shouldn't have to consult a walkthrough just to be able to play a game).I can imagine that when this came out in the sparse game market of the mid-90s, that it was absolutely amazing. I suspect a lot of the positive reviews for it come from people who played it when it first came out. Back then, you wouldn't mind spending hours upon hours playing, even if you were defeated each time. However, games have advanced considerably since then, and its outdated mechanics and unforgiving gameplay make it downright frustrating for new players. Losing is rarely fun.Short version:  If you're looking for a fun strategy game, I recommend buying the reboot, X-COM: Enemy Unknown. It preserves what was great about the original series with updated, simplified mechanics.  If you heard this is a classic and you're curious, I recommend watching a Let's Play of it instead. Those people have played it before and know the "right" way to play the game. It will save you time AND grief!  If you played this before and loved it, yeah, buy it! Or, check out OpenXCom, an open-source clone of the original game which fixes a lot of problems with running the game on modern machines.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												So I finally am sitting down to try out these well renowned classics. First stop is the original X-Com: UFO Defense. Right off the bat I have to give props to whoever was behind the porting. The game runs beautifully and even scales well on a full 1080p display. The sound also is fully functional with only some minor skipping in the opening cutscene. If you were into this game and have a lot of nostalgia for it, then you will love this masterful port.As a brand new player of the X-Com games, I can’t say I have much interest in this original title. I have no doubts that it was a phenomenal experience back upon release, but some games age better than others and the rose tint of nostalgia goggles only works for games you grew up with. UFO Defense has no semblance of a tutorial. I have a feeling that the original game had an awesome manual (as all classic titles did) but Steam doesn’t sell games in boxes. Without a tutorial I had to do a lot of trial and error. Fortunately I understand the premise of the game, but even knowing how the game is supposed to play out I was constantly struggling with the interface and cryptic icons. It took almost 30 minutes of play before I was ever able to see the ground combat and once the mission was underway I quickly lost all patience for the interface. I’m spoiled from all the advancement in interface design and increase in screen real estate, trying to navigate the battlefield and direct my soldiers was nothing but frustrating.X-Com: UFO Defense was the spark that started one of gaming's classic and highly regarded franchises but I don’t think it’s aged well. The port is phenomenal and those who grew up with it will be thrilled with this trip down memory lane. However, newcomers will more than likely be put off.

Cheap enemies that make you have to pretty much restart your game are not challenging. They're annoying and add difficulty for no reason other than to allow the claim 'this game is super difficult! I like fairness in my games, thanks. Back to Frozen Synapse

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This is the original X-COM.  This is for the classic lovers.This game has no in-game tutorial, no in-game help. The control is difficult to use, with many on-screen controls but no keyboard shortcut (luckily OpenXCOM come to help).  But it is a 20 years-old games, what did I expected?  I get used to the control, I accept the graphics, I like the styles of the game.However, the game play is difficult, too difficult.  You entire squads can be killed by one enemy without you find out where he was.  Every time the squads come out of the plane, at least one was killed.  When one or two aliens were killed, a missile/bomb came and the whole squads were killed.If you have played it 20 years ago (first published in 1994), play it now to get a sense of technology advancement in these 20 years or just play it to remind you the good old days.But if you have played the new "Enemy Unknown" and did not played this old game before, I do not recommend you to start playing this.

number of helpful: 15 of 97 people (15%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2012
												Utterly impressive--X-COM represents a classic history lesson in PC strategy games. I was not expecting to see the depth this game provides. Strategy games are not really my preferred genre, but I have to admire the early contributions this game gave to the strategy genre and give props where they are due. Twenty year ago, this was cutting edge stuff.Gamers that haven't played something this aged will have to look beyond the low resolution graphics and clunky user interface to understand that developers used to focus primarily on game play--an aspect this game provides an abundance of. Regardless, other than for nostalgia, history, or research, I would suggest something a little more modern. But if you do decide to give it a shot, this predates in-game tutorials so you'll want to read the manual if you really want to know what is going on...all 134 pages of it.

Posted: July 29, 2014
												I've been playing X-COM since I was six years old, and watching my father play a few years younger.  I can't really just call it a game to me.  It's basically my life.X-COM is not a game that has aged well, in terms of UI, aesthetics, and bugginess.  You are not about to love it for its polish, where the alien grenades look like jelly-filled doughnuts.  You are not about to love it for intuitive controls, it will feel like learning a new language without a dictionary.   However, this game has implanted a long-lasting and recently rekindled legacy in Western strategy games that rivals the influence of the 4X and the East's "Tactics" genres.Even if you don't enjoy it, an extremely remote possibility, it is still worth trying out if only to solidify one's claim as a Strategy game enthusiast.

Posted: November 30, 2010
												Ah, X-COM. A game with a learning curve like running into a brick wall and a margin of error comparable to the pope's patience with me, which is to say almost nil. That said, this is an extremely engaging tactical/stratetic game that demands you exercise the 3P's of X-COM success: Planning, Patience, and Paranoia. You'll be put in charge of what amounts to the UN (but with more guns) and told to fight off incoming swarms of aliens, nick their stuff, and use it against them, then take the fight back to them. Sounds simple enough, but once you go into the game and really get your feet on the ground of your first battle, that changes. Think tactically, use your turns wisely, and never let your soldiers go Rambo, or else you'll end the mission with an even higher casualty count than usual. For those who are already familiar with turn based tactical games, try the Ironman challenge, and only save between missions. A great game series and set that's easy on the processor and the wallet.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												IMO, this is one of if not thee best game ever made.  The amount of depth offered in this game is astonishing.  You will not find a game out there that offers the customizability that this game overs, you literally have control of every aspect all the way down to naming your soldiers.  It does have some issues, but they are far overshadowed by the value you get in this game.Pros:- Customization is out of this world, literally.- Sense of accomplishment you get from completing missions is huge, the battles can really be hard and when you come home with all your guys after the mess you had to mop up it really feels like you accomplished a lot.- Some may hate the difficulty of this game, but I love it.  The aliens really are very intellegent, and if you make too many mistakes it is over.- Love the ability to have to work your way through the game with balance, you have to research, manufactor and choose your battles wisely.Cons:- This game is old, the graphics are really out of date.  Not a big deal to me, but for some this could be a problem.- There are some bugs that are very frustrating, including corrupted saves.  - Ground combat is clunky, not very fluid.  - Game difficulty can be very frustrating.

												A classic. Posted: February 8, 2014
												This is the best game ever created after the original Legend of Zelda.  For its time, there is nothing that even comes close to the total playability of this game.  Even today, this game is about as fun as any game you will play despite its extremely dated graphics.  I remember playing this on my dos based pc game till 5am while having Aliens playing simultaneously in the background when I was in high school.  You actually make a connection with your soldiers that you deploy.  This game is extremely detailed in both the turn based strategy combat missions, and the resource base building strategy elements needed to be successful.  The game progresses at a perfect pace.  From the opening trailer with inspiring music to the final brain battle on Mars, you'll not regret playing this timeless classic.

Posted: January 1, 2011
												A genre defining classic.Just brilliant in all respects. I can quite happily play this on DOSbox for hours on end even today. The player controlls an multi-national defence alliance from a global interface - hires and fires scientists, engineers and soldiers, builds bases and conducts missions to uncover the secrets of an invading alien force. Then they take control of turn based missions that are unpredictable and different on every playthrough. The story culminates in a massive battle with the humans harvesting the alien technology and using it against the invaders. Dynamic gameplay that offers meaningful choices to the player at every stage of the game. Risk vs. reward mechanic that pushes a conservative player out of their comfort zone, and punishes players that get too greedy too quickly. One of my favourite games of all time.10/10

Posted: November 30, 2010
												Ah, X-COM. A game with a learning curve like running into a brick wall and a margin of error comparable to the pope's patience with me, which is to say almost nil. That said, this is an extremely engaging tactical/stratetic game that demands you exercise the 3P's of X-COM success: Planning, Patience, and Paranoia. You'll be put in charge of what amounts to the UN (but with more guns) and told to fight off incoming swarms of aliens, nick their stuff, and use it against them, then take the fight back to them. Sounds simple enough, but once you go into the game and really get your feet on the ground of your first battle, that changes. Think tactically, use your turns wisely, and never let your soldiers go Rambo, or else you'll end the mission with an even higher casualty count than usual. For those who are already familiar with turn based tactical games, try the Ironman challenge, and only save between missions. A great game series and set that's easy on the processor and the wallet.

												Played this game as X-COM: Enemy unknown in the 90´s on my 486 pc. Any good?Really great game and yes the pixels show, I already loved this game back then and still loving it.Fixes:Heres a fix for widescreens (cause my game got stretched and made it ugly) so you can play windowed mode, found it on the internet:originally for apocalypse, but works the same..just look up the xcom ufo defense dirThe DOSBox file to tweak is dosbox.conf.(Be sure to back up the dosbox.conf file before editing it.)To run the game in a 1024×768 window, make the following edits.fullscreen=falsefulldouble=falsefullresolution=originalwindowresolution=1024×768output=ddraw If the game feels a little sluggish running under DOSBox, experiment with the cycles setting. Anywhere between 20000 or 30000 will do.cycles=20000 I have my XCOM working at 1152x864 resolution, works perfectly in windowed mode. Make sure you overwrite the file by clicking on the original file when you save it (by viewing all files you will see the file, click on it overwrite and play).With this fix you can buy the game from steam and still enjoy playing it through steam on a widescreen. Happy gaming!! Works on xcom apocalypse terror from the deep ufo defense.Recommend it?Yes.

Posted: May 31, 2015
												I recall spending hours playing this as a youth.  It was unique at the time. I had never seen anything like it.  It was a thinking game.  You had to use small unit tactics to get the job done, or your squad would be history.  I remember being wowed by discovering the next alien to show up.  It was  a great game then, and it is still a very good game.  No, it hasn't got the awesome visual effects, the incredible sound effects that modern games do, but its got great mechanics. Every mission is a challenge, especially when sectoids are mind controlling you squad members and using them against you.  There is  always element of chaos, where you never know what is going to happen next, and a bit of bad luck can make you have to rethink your tactics on the fly.  Toward the end, some of the missions get pretty routine as your solders get tougher and more experienced, but there is always that one last mission looming ahead; the end game that puts a stop, once and for all, to the alien menace.  You know during in those final few missions you're gearing up or the big one.

												X-Com is a classic for a good reason. Fans of Turn-Based Strategy are sure to enjoy this game, although perhaps that genre alone isn't entirely adequate to describe it. I'd call it a sort of Turn-Based Survival Horror game. Whenever you embark on a new mission, you can never know where the next alien might be hiding - one rash move and your best men could be eviscerated by some unseen alien monstrosity. Fights feel like a genuine struggle to survive the onslaught. This game is very much worth the purchase, and if the emulated nature of the game doesn't appeal to you, OpenXcom is definitely something to check out.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												This is more of my experience playing X-COM: UD and making a few comparisons to XCOM 2012. Btw, I don't play this on Steam.XCOM 2012 was a great game that allowed you to field a maximum of 6 units in a single base throughout the whole game, a good compromise to keep things simple. Well let me tell you about Microprose's X-COM: UFO Defense. This game gives you a worldwide organization, making it more complex, letting you build multiple bases around the world unlike the new XCOM that limits you to one base, making you put all your eggs in one basket, but the new game won't give you that danger, unless it's scripted. UFO Defense does give you that possible danger. When the enemy discovers a base, they're going to make attempts to crash your base with a fairly large death squad. If you survive the first surprise assault on your base, at that point you now know your base is compromised, so either you could increase defenses and wait for another invading party to arrive or you can move everything you're allowed to take with you to another base.Having multiple base, you could have countless operatives stationed around the world and up to 20 can be suited up per mission. That being said, after you give them a name and a weapon, you'll be watching them go down on every wrong turn they take. A seasoned veteran will see good men and women die in this game from the beginning to the end. I usually take around 30 minutes customizing item loadouts for each of my operatives, treating them as individuals only to watch them take plasma to the chest as soon as they walk down the Skyranger's ramp. Instantly killed. At the end of the mission, a handful survive. Don't let the game discourage you, that right from the start, you get the feeling of being the little guy who is fighting an uphill battle and losses are plenty. On a side note: something popular within the community is that you want to increase the emotional impact of losses by giving your operatives familar names.If you want to enhance the game*, while keeping the vanilla experience, go towww.openxcom.orgDownload the latest stable build and overwrite it with the nightly build. Nightly builds are perfectly stable now. You'll get the latest fixes and they update nightlies daily. They also work on this game without expecting any money, so go donate to these wonderful folks.Then if you want to add mods easily and trust me you want mods, go towww.openxcom.com*You need to buy the game so OpenXcom can run. Totally worth it.If you want to chat with other X-COM veterans or general turn-based strategy fans, you could check out the forums from OpenXcom and StrategyCore.

												I've gotta say that this is one of the best tactics games out there.while, at first, I thought that this was really difficult and has a really hard to use gui. I've found that it is actually quite nice. Another thing that impressed me was that most of the technology you get from reverse engineering the aliens tech. so you have to beat it to use it. All the alien technologies in the game have some amount of lore. in addition to that your guys are horrible at aiming until they gain several ranks but they usually dont last long enough for that. I will warn you that this is hard at least at first and just because you beat the mission doesnt mean you will increase your score.It is also cool how the aliens have superior technology so you have to have superior tactics to kill them. most of your guys will die in 1 or 2 shots from the aliens but they can usually stand around 2-3 and sometimes the more powerful aliens can withstand more in the region of 8 shots. In the story, the different countries of the world in their fear of the alien threat have banded together to fund the xcom project to aid in the protection of earth. Each month you are evaluated on your score gain/loss during that month. If you did well they will increase your monthly salary but if you do bad they will decrease it.oh and you can also destroy walls if they get in your way and you have a strong enough gun. (A rifle is strong enough to destroy wooden walls.)I would definitely rate this a 5/5 game

Posted: December 25, 2013
												This game was one of the main games played during my childhood, a game which actually got me into the strategy genre and one which I have the most nostalgic memories of joy and rage.For those of you who have played the most recent X-com remakes (Enemy Unknown and Bureau) this title is VASTLY different, and quite clearly from the screenshots shown above, a fairly dated title at that.  However the gameplay is solid, and those of you looking for a challenging strategic game will not be disappointed.  For some people this is what they will call a "wiki-game", there is no tutorial or instruction on how to play it.  As the newly integrated X-Com Commander, you are left to your own devices to decide how to deal with the alien menace, trying your best to keep your investors happy, your soldiers alive and the aliens dead. Those of you who enjoy the aspect of figuring things out on your own with little to no hand-holding will really appreciate this concept.What I will warn to all of the players who begin, is that with the learning curve aside, the game can be punishingly brutal at times, the aliens start off with better technology and a greater overall advantage over your own forces.  This game will take advantage of any mistake you make and will punish stupidity without mercy.  But for this reason alone, this has made this title the favourite strategy game for a grand audience who have been playing games since the amiga and commodore era, to this day the gameplay is still highly engaging.If you do feel apprehensive about purchasing this title due to it's lack of tutorials or punishing combat, then I suggest you invest your time into one or two Let's Play series on your favourite video hosting websites.  You will no doubt find plenty to give you an idea of what's waiting for you in the cold of space.But even now as I write this, the Steam Winter Sales have been trigged, with X-com getting a 50% discount at it's already low price of £2.99.  Which translates to about less than 5 bucks everywhere else.  I personally find that to be a bit of a steal, but then I have a lot of love for the game.  But if you ever wanted a cheap classical strategy title with challenging gameplay, then by all means, snatch this up.And remember.  In space, nobody can hear you ragequit.

												tl;dr version:A fair price is... - If you like turn based strategy, buy it for $7 or less.- If you don't like this sort of thing, wait until it goes on sale for $3 or less.More details version:Pros:- Lots of tactical decisions. Night/Day missions. Civilian defense missions. Combat tactics.- Lots of weapons, species and lore to research.- Loose win conditions. Ultimately you beat the aliens, but everything in between is your call so long as you don't lose.- A lot of lore and hidden mechanics. Tactics exist and enemies have weaknesses, but you have to find them.- Hugely rewarding experience.Cons:- This game does zero hand holding. There's no tutorial; you'll have to read the manual before you start.- Can be very frustrating. I have had to uninstal this game out of irritation from time to time.- Default steam settings on the Dos Box will take some tweaking so it runs well on your computer. Posted: August 3, 2011
												The original and the best. Apocalypse comes close, but this is the best game of its type ever produced. Simple tactical gameplay surrounded by a deep global logistics setup lets you investigate the alien threat and start to fight back, defending as much of the planet as you can to make sure the world's governments continue to fund your efforts.If you've never played any of the X-COM series, this really is a case of the original being the best - especially for the price. Closely followed by X-COM Apocalypse, and the less said about the other games the better (unless you want to rip out all your hair trying to beat the ludicrously difficult second game, Terror From The Deep). If the dated graphics and interface put you off, take a look at UFO Aftermath. Made by a different company, it's a more modern tribute to the X-COM series and measures up reasonably well.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Over the last 15 years, I've logged at least 1,000 hours in this game. Initially, when I first played it back in 2001, I didn't know any strategies, secrets, tactics, hints, guides, or helpful advice existed. I just played and got my squads wrecked, over and over again. But, I kept playing. It was that good! Ten years later, I played it again, because I learned about the strategy guides which exist now. The game was even more exciting, because I could control the battles. Again I played in 2014, refreshing my experience and reliving the plight of X-Com. Anyway, down to the details.The graphics, by today's standards, are cheesy, super-pixelated and difficult to interpret (at times). Even cheesier is the quality of music/sound effects. However, the sound is probably the single most-definitive characteristic in the game. The ominous sound effects severely impact the immersion in the battle. Without realizing it, I get sucked into the tension, because of the ominous pulsating background noise. Finally, the turn-based battlescape strategy style which beckons for perfection. Master strategists would struggle to survive some of those battles. One word: Chryssalids.TLDR: Sci-Fi themed, turn-based strategy (with a side of Real-time Spaceship chase scenarios), in-depth immersion. P.S. - If you can't beat em, get a bigger Blaster Launcher.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												I'm old enough to have played this when it was new, and it's still good fun today. Back in 1993 it was the long-awaited follow-up to Laser Squad, and successfully expanded the concept into isometric 3D, with a fun strategy element. It has a lot of quirks although unlike the sequel (Terror from the Deep) there aren't any game-breaking bugs. The interface has the kind of icon-heavy design that was popular at the time but hasn't dated well. The gameplay however is still solid, and it's still tricky, especially if you decide not to chicken out and abort the mission when your crack troops get slaughtered. Playing it many years later it's entertaining to try different strategies - rather than use the overpowered heavy plasma rifle, why not use human weapons only? Or omit the laser guns and use projectiles, or never use tanks etc.The difficulty curve is famously unforgiving. Mission one is easy, but it then becomes very hard, gets a bit easier, and then becomes very hard again. Once you get over the final hump the remaining battles become a kerb-stomp, as you have psychic soldiers and nigh-invincible flying tanks, but until that point you learn not to get too attached to your soldiers, which is frustrating because their stats improve with time, and it's horrible when your 80TU flying-suited supersoldier is dropped by a lucky shot from a monster hiding behind underneath the exit ramp. Typically the game throws a terror mission at you in the first couple of months, which resembles the opening of Saving Private Ryan - your soldiers are gunned-down before they have a chance to deploy. Then alien mind control causes the survivors to blow up their comrades. Eventually you get to do the same to the aliens, and it's sweet revenge.The Steam version runs in DOSBox. There's a popular fan mod called XComUtil which is compatible with the Steam edition, and it's recommended because it fixes a few bugs. For example the game's original difficulty menu didn't work properly - it always reverted to "beginner" at the end of turn one - which was a mixed blessing because the game was still very hard.This is also one of those fondly-remembered titles that defied attempts to write a good sequel - reminiscent of Mechwarrior 2 or Syndicate in that respect. The franchise was extended into real-time 3D space action and then first-person 3D, but the original is still the best. The graphics have a subtle manga look that was very novel in the west in 1993, and still looks good today.I haven't played the direct sequel, Terror from the Deep, which replaced the graphics and tweaked the gameplay; it's apparently very buggy and gets monotonous, although for the current low price I will probably try it out at some point.Here in the UK X-Com was released as UFO: Enemy Unknown, and I always wondered if it was loosely based on the old Gerry Anderson series UFO.

Posted: March 9, 2015
												XCom brings alot to the table for its age. This game revolves around turn based tactical combat during encounters and an global management system. There is a currency system in game and base layout/management. XCom is a classic and even if you've never beaten the game it's still fun to play so many years after its release.  Nothing beats that feeling when you prepare your crews and set up base in anticipation of detecting your first UFO on radar. When it happens you won't forget that rush when you attempt to down your first UFO and not to mention the threatening dread and creepfactor when you deploy to examine the crash site.  While the graphics are dated there's something about XCom that really gets it right in so many aspects. Once you get used to research chains, selling crafted equipment and navigating the interface it won't seem so overwhelming. Once you are familiarized with the AI's nasty little tricks and how to manage your team's items and movement XCom really reveals it's charm. With little need for powerful hardware and a save feature available at any time there's huge casual replay values. There is even a mobile version called PocketUFO that you can find online for your phone. It's amazing how well XCom holds up after so much time.

Posted: December 2, 2010
												Very fun turn based battle strategy game. It was awesome back in 1995. It is still pretty great! I loved this game before the turn of the century! lol!! I can't believe I had found a 3 pack of XCOM games on sale for $5 or $15 back then. What a great game!I absolutely love how if you shoot High Explosives into a wall, it can disentregrate! Pros:Can always buy more soldiers!All soldiers have newly generated stats!Soldiers can gain ranks and increase their current stats!Soldiers with high strength are a good choice for heavy weapons.Heavy weapons have 2-3 types of ammo. AP-Armor Piercing; HE-High Explosive; I-Incindiary(Fire)A great selection of grenades and even high explosives.Why bother with high explosives, if you can assign a soldier to carry a rocket launcher! (lol)Can research recovered alien weapons and aircraft!Tactics and gun fire during battle are great!If you leave enough movement points for a soldier at the end of the round, they will be able to fire their weapons at enemies during the enemy's round, if the enemy walks into their view.Can kneel to increase accuracy and decrease size.Lots of different types of aliens to fight, recover, and research!Can capture aliens for research!There is never an easy fight just because you have the best armor available. You still have to use your brains.Your factories can build everything you have researched, except for Elerium 115.Need for the resource Elerium 115 forces you to locate more aliens to advance your equipment.Cons:All soldiers are desired to have high accuracy. Unless you use them as a medic or psychic.Can not train soldiers outside of combat.Soldiers can be one-shot killed with heavy weapons, even while wearing heavy armor.There is no quick way to run through 10 battles.Battles become repetitive, but by this time you will have aquired enough money to explore using big weapons during combat. (Which caused me to use the Ghost Buster's theory of blowing holes in walls at and around any enemy seen, no matter how much damage it would cause. lol. "Its a little alien... Arm the rocket launcher! Auto fire the incindiary explosives from the auto cannon!" BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! KA-BOOM!)Small bugs that you would never normally see. (Assigning more than 256 scientists to the same research project will cause a roll-over into negative integers. This will either cause you to have an infinite number of scientists for many projects, or if you ever roll the number of available scientists to zero - it will cause you to have zero scientists with zero lab space for the scientists. -But like I said, you will NEVER see this bug while playing a regular game. But a regular game would take over a hundred hours to play. Giving yourself a hundred million dollars will give you the means to build 6 research laboratories (300 lab seats), and then hiring 300 scientists to research. What would normally take over half a year of game time to research with earned funds and two dozen scientists.) Posted: December 25, 2013
												This game was one of the main games played during my childhood, a game which actually got me into the strategy genre and one which I have the most nostalgic memories of joy and rage.For those of you who have played the most recent X-com remakes (Enemy Unknown and Bureau) this title is VASTLY different, and quite clearly from the screenshots shown above, a fairly dated title at that.  However the gameplay is solid, and those of you looking for a challenging strategic game will not be disappointed.  For some people this is what they will call a "wiki-game", there is no tutorial or instruction on how to play it.  As the newly integrated X-Com Commander, you are left to your own devices to decide how to deal with the alien menace, trying your best to keep your investors happy, your soldiers alive and the aliens dead. Those of you who enjoy the aspect of figuring things out on your own with little to no hand-holding will really appreciate this concept.What I will warn to all of the players who begin, is that with the learning curve aside, the game can be punishingly brutal at times, the aliens start off with better technology and a greater overall advantage over your own forces.  This game will take advantage of any mistake you make and will punish stupidity without mercy.  But for this reason alone, this has made this title the favourite strategy game for a grand audience who have been playing games since the amiga and commodore era, to this day the gameplay is still highly engaging.If you do feel apprehensive about purchasing this title due to it's lack of tutorials or punishing combat, then I suggest you invest your time into one or two Let's Play series on your favourite video hosting websites.  You will no doubt find plenty to give you an idea of what's waiting for you in the cold of space.But even now as I write this, the Steam Winter Sales have been trigged, with X-com getting a 50% discount at it's already low price of £2.99.  Which translates to about less than 5 bucks everywhere else.  I personally find that to be a bit of a steal, but then I have a lot of love for the game.  But if you ever wanted a cheap classical strategy title with challenging gameplay, then by all means, snatch this up.And remember.  In space, nobody can hear you ragequit.

Posted: April 8, 2011
												I always found the brutal difficulty of X-Com to be peculiarly satisfying. For the first few missions the best you can hope for are pyrrhic victories. Your untested and underequipped soldiers are just no match for the high-tech alien menace. They raid the cities of the earth with impunity. France drops funding and begins to conspire with the aliens. You may begin to despair.As you suffer, though, your squad grows more and more powerful. You unlock new technologies that put you on par with the invaders. You finally have a chance. The victories come more regularly, as do exciting new discoveries.By the end game you have cultivated an army of power-armored supersoldiers with terrible psychic powers. Your enemies quail at the sight of your squad. Once terrible foes are now your puppets, forced to gun down their comrades or simply drop plasma grenades at their own feet.It is immensely satisfying, in a way that few games today are. Will we ever get a proper new X-Com? Of course not.Update: OH WAIT WE DID!

												My favorite game ever.  The (pioneering) combination of tactical combat, with strategic base management, makes the game very non-linear.
