												I've been playing X-COM since I was six years old, and watching my father play a few years younger.  I can't really just call it a game to me.  It's basically my life.X-COM is not a game that has aged well, in terms of UI, aesthetics, and bugginess.  You are not about to love it for its polish, where the alien grenades look like jelly-filled doughnuts.  You are not about to love it for intuitive controls, it will feel like learning a new language without a dictionary.   However, this game has implanted a long-lasting and recently rekindled legacy in Western strategy games that rivals the influence of the 4X and the East's "Tactics" genres.Even if you don't enjoy it, an extremely remote possibility, it is still worth trying out if only to solidify one's claim as a Strategy game enthusiast.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												I'm old enough to have played this when it was new, and it's still good fun today. Back in 1993 it was the long-awaited follow-up to Laser Squad, and successfully expanded the concept into isometric 3D, with a fun strategy element. It has a lot of quirks although unlike the sequel (Terror from the Deep) there aren't any game-breaking bugs. The interface has the kind of icon-heavy design that was popular at the time but hasn't dated well. The gameplay however is still solid, and it's still tricky, especially if you decide not to chicken out and abort the mission when your crack troops get slaughtered. Playing it many years later it's entertaining to try different strategies - rather than use the overpowered heavy plasma rifle, why not use human weapons only? Or omit the laser guns and use projectiles, or never use tanks etc.The difficulty curve is famously unforgiving. Mission one is easy, but it then becomes very hard, gets a bit easier, and then becomes very hard again. Once you get over the final hump the remaining battles become a kerb-stomp, as you have psychic soldiers and nigh-invincible flying tanks, but until that point you learn not to get too attached to your soldiers, which is frustrating because their stats improve with time, and it's horrible when your 80TU flying-suited supersoldier is dropped by a lucky shot from a monster hiding behind underneath the exit ramp. Typically the game throws a terror mission at you in the first couple of months, which resembles the opening of Saving Private Ryan - your soldiers are gunned-down before they have a chance to deploy. Then alien mind control causes the survivors to blow up their comrades. Eventually you get to do the same to the aliens, and it's sweet revenge.The Steam version runs in DOSBox. There's a popular fan mod called XComUtil which is compatible with the Steam edition, and it's recommended because it fixes a few bugs. For example the game's original difficulty menu didn't work properly - it always reverted to "beginner" at the end of turn one - which was a mixed blessing because the game was still very hard.This is also one of those fondly-remembered titles that defied attempts to write a good sequel - reminiscent of Mechwarrior 2 or Syndicate in that respect. The franchise was extended into real-time 3D space action and then first-person 3D, but the original is still the best. The graphics have a subtle manga look that was very novel in the west in 1993, and still looks good today.I haven't played the direct sequel, Terror from the Deep, which replaced the graphics and tweaked the gameplay; it's apparently very buggy and gets monotonous, although for the current low price I will probably try it out at some point.Here in the UK X-Com was released as UFO: Enemy Unknown, and I always wondered if it was loosely based on the old Gerry Anderson series UFO.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												Short: X-COM UFO Defense is simply a fantastic and immersive strategy game. It is very complex, but is still easy to learn and understand. The game gives the player lots of options and freedom in defeating the alien invasion. The variety of options also creates a large replay value. Long: To begin, the Windows 7 version runs via DosBox. The default settings limit the cycle speed, meaning the game can have very low FPS counts sometimes. Manually changing the cycle limit will allow you to increase the FPS for smoother gameplay.The controls via DosBox are all cursor-based, as far as I know. The keyboard is simply not used at all. Keyboard controls could be useful, so I will say this is a con. The game itself has tons of options for players. There are some base management aspects, where you can build new facilities in the X-COM bases or build new bases altogether. This stuff is pretty simple (not really any micro managing) but allows for a large variety of different base configurations. Supplies and personel (soldiers, scientists, and engineers) can be bought/hired and sold/fired and can also be transferred between bases. Scientists research new technology from base labs which can allow your engineers to manufactor new weapons, vehicles, armor, or other useful things. Funding is a concern; your funding is automatically adjusted each month based on your performance in stopping the alien menace. You can also gain funds by selling supplies you find or produce.The geo map view looks nice (for Dos) and is where you order your aircraft to shoot down UFOs or to land squads at landed UFOs/crashed UFOs/terror sites/alien bases. When you land at a site, you can customize the loadout of each soldier based on what equipment was in the landing craft. Tactical combat is solid but difficult; raw recruits and even semi-skilled soldiers are absolutely terrible shots. There is a variety of different weapons, grenades, and other equipment that your soldiers can use. There are several types of aliens that are mostly quite unique from each other. After neutralizing all aliens at a site, you also automatically collect their loot--the alien weaponry and supplies can be used by your soldiers or sold for profit. By researching new technologies and interrogating captured aliens, the end-game content and final missions to beat the game are revealed. Overall, it is a very enjoyable experience and the variety of options means there is a great degree of replayability. I highly recommend the game.

												IMO, this is one of if not thee best game ever made.  The amount of depth offered in this game is astonishing. It does have some issues, but they are far overshadowed by the value you get in this game.Pros:- Customization is out of this world, literally.- Sense of accomplishment you get from completing missions is huge, the battles can really be hard and when you come home with all your guys after the mess you had to mop up it really feels like you accomplished a lot.- Some may hate the difficulty of this game, but I love it.  The aliens really are very intellegent, and if you make too many mistakes it is over.- Love the ability to have to work your way through the game with balance, you have to research, manufactor and choose your battles wisely.Cons:- This game is old, the graphics are really out of date.  Not a big deal to me, but for some this could be a problem.- There are some bugs that are very frustrating, including corrupted saves.  - Ground combat is clunky, not very fluid.  - Game difficulty can be very frustrating.

Posted: January 30, 2012
												An incredibly deep strategy experience. X-COM never pulls any punches as you work hundreds of scientists over countless sleepless nights, trying to understand alien technology before your feeble human forces are swept aside. A UFO is spotted over Europe, and an alien terror mission is destroying a village in Africa. Where do you send aid? What do you do when the troops hit the ground, and what happens if you discover that you are dealing with two different aliens with two different intentions? With limited funding, balanced on the moods of the temperamental leaders of the world, you must find a way to answer these questions. But you have to answer them quickly, because when the alien threat learns of your mission they will be coming for you next. X-COM is a game of real consequences; you know what the stakes are. Anyone who enjoys a game that will be just as immensely rewarding as it is unreservedly punishing should dawn the title of X-COM Commander.

Posted: March 9, 2015
												XCom brings alot to the table for its age. This game revolves around turn based tactical combat during encounters and an global management system. There is a currency system in game and base layout/management. XCom is a classic and even if you've never beaten the game it's still fun to play so many years after its release.  Nothing beats that feeling when you prepare your crews and set up base in anticipation of detecting your first UFO on radar. When it happens you won't forget that rush when you attempt to down your first UFO and not to mention the threatening dread and creepfactor when you deploy to examine the crash site.  While the graphics are dated there's something about XCom that really gets it right in so many aspects. Once you get used to research chains, selling crafted equipment and navigating the interface it won't seem so overwhelming. Once you are familiarized with the AI's nasty little tricks and how to manage your team's items and movement XCom really reveals it's charm. With little need for powerful hardware and a save feature available at any time there's huge casual replay values. There is even a mobile version called PocketUFO that you can find online for your phone. It's amazing how well XCom holds up after so much time.

Posted: December 2, 2010
												Very fun turn based battle strategy game. It was awesome back in 1995. It is still pretty great! I loved this game before the turn of the century! lol!! I can't believe I had found a 3 pack of XCOM games on sale for $5 or $15 back then. What a great game!I absolutely love how if you shoot High Explosives into a wall, it can disentregrate! Pros:Can always buy more soldiers!All soldiers have newly generated stats!Soldiers can gain ranks and increase their current stats!Soldiers with high strength are a good choice for heavy weapons.Heavy weapons have 2-3 types of ammo. AP-Armor Piercing; HE-High Explosive; I-Incindiary(Fire)A great selection of grenades and even high explosives.Why bother with high explosives, if you can assign a soldier to carry a rocket launcher! (lol)Can research recovered alien weapons and aircraft!Tactics and gun fire during battle are great!If you leave enough movement points for a soldier at the end of the round, they will be able to fire their weapons at enemies during the enemy's round, if the enemy walks into their view.Can kneel to increase accuracy and decrease size.Lots of different types of aliens to fight, recover, and research!Can capture aliens for research!There is never an easy fight just because you have the best armor available. You still have to use your brains.Your factories can build everything you have researched, except for Elerium 115.Need for the resource Elerium 115 forces you to locate more aliens to advance your equipment.Cons:All soldiers are desired to have high accuracy. Unless you use them as a medic or psychic.Can not train soldiers outside of combat.Soldiers can be one-shot killed with heavy weapons, even while wearing heavy armor.There is no quick way to run through 10 battles.Battles become repetitive, but by this time you will have aquired enough money to explore using big weapons during combat. (Which caused me to use the Ghost Buster's theory of blowing holes in walls at and around any enemy seen, no matter how much damage it would cause. lol. "Its a little alien... Arm the rocket launcher! Auto fire the incindiary explosives from the auto cannon!" BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! KA-BOOM!)Small bugs that you would never normally see. (Assigning more than 256 scientists to the same research project will cause a roll-over into negative integers. This will either cause you to have an infinite number of scientists for many projects, or if you ever roll the number of available scientists to zero - it will cause you to have zero scientists with zero lab space for the scientists. -But like I said, you will NEVER see this bug while playing a regular game. But a regular game would take over a hundred hours to play. Giving yourself a hundred million dollars will give you the means to build 6 research laboratories (300 lab seats), and then hiring 300 scientists to research. What would normally take over half a year of game time to research with earned funds and two dozen scientists.) For some reason, this seems to have caused another bug where I am not shown what I researched when research is complete. But playing this game for a full nother 500 hours is not what I had in mind. I just want to beat the game, since I no longer have my save file from 1996.My old 2010 review follows:"However, I did get bored when I started tracking the aliens back to their home planet in space. Became a huge amount of repetition, taking over space ships and the alien home base. When I got bored I stopped playing, even though I was really close to the end game. Repetition = torture in my book.Very fun game! Wish they would make a 'good' sequal that wasn't the same game over and over again. For example, XCOM 2 was the same game as XCOM 1, but in the oceans of earth instead of on land. But all the equipment was changed and modified to be underwater equipment. I'm sure the aliens were different too."

Posted: November 24, 2016
												So, from 1995 onwards, I've played X-COM: UFO Defense (or as it was known in Europe: X-COM: UFO - Enemy Unknown) ... Over the years I have gone through painstaking efforts to ensure that I retain the ability to play the game. I kept a DOS-operated 486 PC for years until the Windows-compatible XCOM Gold edition came out, then kept an XP computer (actually still keeping it) so I could play that... I have not played it much on Steam, naturally, because I play it on the older computer anyways... Over the past twenty one years (as of 2016 when this review is written) I've clocked upwards of 1000 hours on the game, having beaten it on Superhuman difficulty several times, including, once, playing it IRONMAN style.The game is visually crude, was visually crude even in 1994. That's the only downside in an otherwise groundbreaking game that still has value today. The sound is basic 1994 sound, with good atmospheric music.The strategic level of the game is remarkable all by itself... where you place your bases, what your radar coverage and aerial coverage look like, all those make a signifcant difference. The alien invaders step up their efforts regardless of your progress so if you can't keep up, you'll be overwhelmed. managing your resources, starting from money and equipment and especially your manpower, research capabilities and what you research with them can and will make or break your gameyour soldiers stats are one of the most impressive things in the game. modern XCOM games have dumbed it down much but in this one, your squad's performance depends on a variety of complex stats - from Time Units (which determine how much your soldier can do in a turn), health and accuracy, to deeper stats like reactions (which determines a soldier's likelihood of taking an opportunity fire during the alien turn), bravery (which would determine how your soldier will get through shaking moments like seeing his squad mates die in front of his eyes) and strength (and I'll get to that below)... My strategy has been, for many years, to rename soldiers and add quick reference letters to designate best use for them at a glance (Like Helga Richter S [for Sniper] or Manfred Berger G [for Grenadier]) The tactical level starts at the strategic map, when UFOs appear on the map. You can try and intercept them or, if you are daring, try to see if they'll land and hit them on the ground. An intact UFO will grant much better loot but the catch is that it's intact and has all of its crew. Plus, there's no guarantee that UFO will land... and be wary of engaging the aliens on the ground at night time... equipping your troops is fairly straight forward, except that if you give a rocket launcher and three rockets to some poor schmuck that has low strength, the result will be comically bad. Items that are completely missing from more advanced games like smoke grenades (that have an actual usage for screening purposes) or thermal flares to light up the night make for an add layer of equipment to consider. Use of proximity grenades to mine chokepoints or incindeary ammo as a way to provide extra lighting during night missions adds as well. The environment is very destructible and in fact, you'd often find yourself thinking "i can move around that corner... or I can destroy the wall" and realize that destroying the wall will probably be safer... the aliens are varied and deadly, especially at night when they can see much better than you... initial alien encounters include not so tough aliens like the Sectoids... but when they bring up one of their Cyberdiscs or when the tougher Mutons show up, you'll be running for cover... The game doesn't have a boolean overwatch mode. Instead, if a soldier (or an alien) finished their turn with enough time units for a snapshot with their weapon and during the enemy's turn, they see movement from an enemy that has a smaller combined number of Reactions and Time Units, they will take a opportunity fire.. it can really ruin someone's day The game mechanics are complex and it allows for a good replayability... it's tense, it's difficult and it's fun...It's what Chess would have been like if the Persians invented it today

Posted: March 7, 2016
												This is *the* classic X-COM, which I spent countless hours playing in my youth(?) and getting my nether regions handed to me. The premise is simple: Hostile aliens are invading earth, and you have to bring down their UFOs, handle crash sites, stop them from terrorizing civilization, etc. You can customize your ships, crew, soldiers (down to renaming them), and your base. I heard a rumor the Steam version is the bugfix-rewrite OpenXCOM, but the version I received is just DOSbox running the original. So, it is not bug free. However, it is just as immersive, atmospheric, and all of those adjectives I can throw into a glowing review, as I can remember. The tactical battles are a balance of exciting and harrowing turn-based fun. I would say this game has stood the test of time.Advice for playing this game: Find the manual. Read it! Save early. Save often. Realise it's not a brand new game. Experiment. And of course, have lots of fun.

												This is one of the games that got me into steam, partly becasue its nhy-impossible to find elsewhere. It has survived the tests of time far better than any other game that has comes to mind. However if your not a fan of Turnbased strategy games then its probably not for you. It starts off fairly indepth and just keeps digging. If you do start playing I recommend researching the Blaster Launcher as soon as you aquire one from the Aliens. Best weapon in the game, thank god for the most part the game isn't concerned with collateral damage.Edit: Still one of the best games on PC IMHO and while the new titles are a nice step towards more complex games of yore and while they are visually stunning I still don't feel that they hold a candle to the depth of the original.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												Even today, after so many years it still remains an absolute classic and a must have for anyone who enjoys strategy and/or turn based games. X-COM: UFO Defense is very complex. It's a bit overwhelming, especially to newcomers, but after mastering all of its mechanics it proves to be highly rewarding and satisfying. Probably the best thing about this title are its replayability and difficulty, which even on the lowest of 5 levels, is very high. Soundtrack, although being extremely simple, fits the game perfectly and helps creating mysterious and dark atmosphere, which is extremely addictive and enjoyable.There are some issues, like the well known difficulty bug, but all of them can be fixed with XcomUtil.I can't think of any other game, which keeps me coming back so often for so many years. X-COM: UFO Defense is one the best games ever made, period. Recommended for the Steam "Test of Time" Award

Posted: December 27, 2010
												My favourite PC game of all time, period.The first X-COM is the game I played many times, first back when I was a kid, on an old 386SX, monochrome graphics and no sound, and now on my new multicore rig, with the same enthusiasm as before. A great blend of base management, chasing UFOs all over the globe, and tactical isometric turn-based strategy, it is THE definition of 'oldschool'. Newer attempts to re-create the success of this game were more or less futile and lacking.Its graphics have aged exceptionally well (now it would be classified as 'pixelart'), the music is dramatic and suits the tense atmosphere perfectly, and there's that amazing feeling of reward when you've finally cleared the UFO crash site of alien lifeforms... Dang, I think I'll go play some more. And prod Ethereals with stun sticks. And guide blaster bombs through alien base corridors. And get horribly devastated by Chryssalids. Oh boy.*Edit* it's 2016 and this is still my all-time favorite game of all time. Seriously, go get it.

Posted: August 29, 2012
												If you're not big on your cult classic game knowledge, let me tell you a bit about X-Com UFO Defense.  You are the commander of a badass 90's cool task force set up by the UN to defend the planet against Alien Invaders.  You do this by building up your bases around the planet and watching for invading UFOs and then sending out jets and squads of Huge dudes with badass haircuts and big guns to murder aliens and protect civilians. It's got an awesome top-down, 3rd-person, strategy control scheme for the fights, and surprisingly tactical and cover conscious combat.I can tell you, even as a guy who never played this game when it was first made, that it is a hell of a lot of fun.  And if you're a fan of Strategy games, sci-fi, and persistent troopers that you need to level up and keep alive. Posted: February 18, 2016
												Like others, this is a game I have very fond memories of - playing late at night, in the dark, on my old trust 386/40 machine back in the mid-90's.  You control a squad of soldiers looking to beat back and eventually destroy an alien menace bent on taking over our planet.  The control of individual soldiers both in equipment layout and physical movement during battle is something I have yet to see another game duplicate to this level.  It's great campy fun to research alien technology and eventually turn it against the aliens themselves in the form of better weapons and technology.  Sure, the graphics are a bit dated by todays standards but great gameplay never goes out of fashion!  And hey, this game will run great on even the oldest of laptops if you need it to.  This remains one of my all-time favorite games, right up there with Civilization, Unreal Tournament, and Half-Life as a must-own classic.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												Oh man, love they made this functional on new pc's have spent thousands of hours playing this game in the past.Worth all 4 mb of hard drive space and every penny.*For the noobs- instructions*Build a Base between as many countries as possible-Get a large radar-Soldier stats matter- (buy more sell crappy ones- Bravery very important 60+ allows 2 mental hits)Win the game by research- (you need scientists and engineers)Sell crap you dont need to free up stores in begining-Use avalanch missiles-Rearm ships-Electro Flares for night missions-Smoke bombs for exiting ship on terror missions-Pick a few countries to protect at all cost- nothing in nothing out for long gameplay.-Build radar bases- with soul purpose of expanding veiw-VERY small ships are the most dangerous, they contain infultration leaders that steel goverment funding.--(dont let them land-shoot em down)Terror ships (medium) are second most dangerous, they do terror sites and cause governments to decrease funding (dont let them land-shoot em down)small Large ships are scouts and research vessles, good for income and you can let them land then send a ranger in for a full 2 mill per run from sell sack-Very large ships are for attacking your bases and resupplying alien ground bases-If you see 4-5 large ships cluctered in one area one of three things is happening- 1. Aliens are building a ground base. 2 Aliens are supplying a ground base you don't see send patrols to the area to find it. 3. They are about to attack an XCOM base you built, hope your base defenses are up to par.-OpenXcom- makes the game better, however is not needed.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												This is *the* classic X-COM, which I spent countless hours playing in my youth(?) and getting my nether regions handed to me. The premise is simple: Hostile aliens are invading earth, and you have to bring down their UFOs, handle crash sites, stop them from terrorizing civilization, etc. You can customize your ships, crew, soldiers (down to renaming them), and your base. I heard a rumor the Steam version is the bugfix-rewrite OpenXCOM, but the version I received is just DOSbox running the original. So, it is not bug free. However, it is just as immersive, atmospheric, and all of those adjectives I can throw into a glowing review, as I can remember. The tactical battles are a balance of exciting and harrowing turn-based fun. I would say this game has stood the test of time.Advice for playing this game: Find the manual. Read it! Save early. Save often. Realise it's not a brand new game. Experiment. And of course, have lots of fun.

												The original. Still unmatched, not just because of its tactical depth, but also because of its dark and foreboding atmosphere. No other game has reached this games ability to tell unique and dynamic story, be it the slow - and sometimes inevitable -descent of your squad or the rise from the ashes after a devastating blow. Never have I feared so much for the digital lives of my squad members. Never have I felt so utterly powerless, but never have I felt better after beating a game and kicking some alien butt.10 out of 10 Squadmates

Posted: May 27, 2016
												Amazing game!Great game for its time and it still holds of fairly well because it was so well made and thought out. This is the game that started the whole xcom saga and made big a whole concept of squad turn bases strategy that is brutal and unforgiving for both sides.If you like strategy, complexity, decition making, base building, tactical combat, resource management, research and if nothing else destroying aliens this is the game for you.It would take a long page and bore you to say everything about the game thats good and bad. Just know its a big huge complicated game. I will say some of the mechanics are still not done in the reboot games of enemy within and xcom 2 and wish they were. Sadly some of the complexity bogs the game down a lot. Everything is big. Lots of staff, weapons, bases, research ect. The game is very un streamlined. Some ways its beautiful and other ways just painful. I do enjoy the Turn Units system of turns. Each unit has points on its turn to use any way they want. Everything uses points, walking, attacking (depending on weapon), turning (yes turning since you have a facing view of hm 1/4), walking (again ya agian as in walking up stairs or rough terrain is more), crouching (ya you can do that as it increases your aim) ect. It gave great flexability. It means if you dont move and have a uhm low TU cost weapon you could get many overwatch shots off not just 1 burst.Any how its an amazing game. If you like indepth complex squad strategy with some base building and research involved you MUST play this as the grand dady of them all. You have to play and beat this game at least 1 time! Beware its a hard game and you will probably lose many handfulls of soldiers. Its sad but hay its war as long as you are killing say 1-2 handfuls of aliens and only lose 0-2 soldiers you are still by the numbers winning so congratulatoins. Early on brace your self to lose several soldiers a mission. Also note that any point if the game a max damage crit shot can kill any of your soldiers so dont get too attached. Its just war sorry.The 2nd game Terror From The Deep did stream line the game fairly well but was a 2 steps forward 1 step back having its own new problems.
